PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination Against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President, and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State'. And
Whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1).
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women; Believing that its implementation would result in:
1. Undue cost to the Nation at this time.

2. ''The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels'' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

3. The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
4. The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our Nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. We the undersigned citizens of Australia,
Believing that men and women are equal but different,
Convinced that Australia can provide equal opportunity for all citizens without foreign treaties,
Concerned that ratifying the UN Discrimination Convention would give a Communist-dominated international committee the power to judge Australia's laws,
Humbly Petition that your Honourable House will not ratify the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. The concerns which people around the World have for the increasing stockpiles of weapons of mass destruction;
2. The global concern that any nuclear exchange will inflict on humanity unimaginable death and suffering;
3. The vulnerability that Australians will face in any nuclear conflict between the major powers;
4. The public concern that Government should explore all avenues to ensure that the nuclear threat is eliminated.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Australian Parliament establish a Senate Select Committee on Nuclear Disarmament and Peace to investigate the creation of a Ministry of Peace and Nuclear Disarmament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Scheyville Airport, New South Wales
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That an airport in the north-western region (commonly called Scheyville) imposes disastrous economic, environmental and social costs on our community.
2. An airport would destroy 2,000 households and impose upheaval, noise and pollution on one million people presently unaffected.
3. The cost of an airport in the north-western region is greater than the alternatives, whilst fog and close proximity to RAAF Base Richmond would make operations impractical.
4. It would destroy the historic village of Pitt Town, environmentally important wetlands, and their unique adherent wildlife.
5. Your petitioners reject these proposals and call for endorsement of the MANS Committee findings.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Metric System
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth objection to the Metric system and request the Government to restore the Imperial system.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That all members of the Women's Services 1939-45 War qualify as ''Australian Soldier'' under the Defence Service Homes Act for loans because on voluntarily joining the Australian Forces they took the oath to resist His Majesty's enemies making themselves available for combat duty in War Zones, and according to Acts and Regulations of the period the Military women had enlisted for service anywhere, some Naval women to sail in any waters, with all servicewomen available for service in Papua New Guinea.

As those members of the Royal Australian Navy, the Australian Imperial Force and the Royal Australian Air Force of 1939-45 War who were not sent to War Zones are granted loans, refusal to grant eligibility to all Ex-servicewoman of 1939- 45 War is unjust and unfair.

Your Petitioners therefore humbly pray that you amend the Defence Service Homes Act by repealing Sub-section 4 (2A) (b) (c) (d) of the Principal Act as amended by No. 137 of 1978, and grant eligibility to all members of the Women's Royal Australian Naval Service, the Australian Women's Army Service, the Women's Auxiliary Australian Air Force, the Australian Army Medical Women's Service, and the Voluntary Aid Detachment of 1939-45 War.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, concerned with the cut in funding to the Brisbane Airport, concerned that this cut means loss of jobs, concerned that this cut could seriously affect the economy of Queensland:
Humbly petition the Senate to request the Australian Government to:
1. Reverse its decision to cut funding to the Brisbane Airport.
2. Abide by the guarantee given by the Minister for Housing and Construction that the Airport would receive priority funding.
3. Assure the citizens of Queensland that the Brisbane Airport as the domestic and economic gateway to this State will be fully completed by 1987.

PETITION.TITLE: Post-School Education Sector
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that the post-school education sector has been neglected in recent years .

(13) Expanding enrolments to open access to education.
(14) Compensating institutions for the costs of amalgamation.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable the Speaker and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that:

The Universal Declaration of Human Rights affirms the principle of the inadmissibility of discrimination and proclaims that all human beings are born free and equal in dignity and rights and that everyone is entitled to all the rights and freedoms set forth therein, without distinction of any kind including distinction based on sex.

However extensive discrimination against women continues to exist. It is an obstacle to the participation of women on equal terms with men, in the political , social, economic and cultural life of this country. It hampers the growth of the prosperity of society and the family and makes more difficult the full development of the potentialities of women in the service of this country and of humanity.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Commonwealth Government will act to ratify the convention on the elimination of all forms of discrimination against women.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report touches the whole question of superannuation payable to Commonwealth Government employees. It is a very interesting document. It draws our attention to the many salient features of those schemes and compares them with similar benefits available to those in the private sector and, indeed, to other parts of the public sector. I draw the particular attention of the Senate to the report. I think it is relevant to note that the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations is, as I understand it, currently undertaking a review in the statutory authority area as well on this very question. The review was commenced last year under the chairmanship of Senator Peter Rae.

One or two facts are salient and can be drawn from this report. For instance, if we were to compare, on an average, the new entrant contribution rate payable by the employer on behalf of employees under such schemes as this, the percentage of salaries would approximate the following: In relation to private schemes providing lump sums the rate is about 9 per cent; in relation to those providing pension benefits as distinct from lump sums, the contribution by employers is of the order of 12.5 per cent; and in relation to schemes in the public sector-Commonwealth and State Government employment-the employer contribution is in excess of 20 per cent of salary. In the case of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme it is 21.5 per cent. I think those figures draw our attention to some very important facts, Mr President. Clearly, payments to people receiving lump sums require a far lower contribution by employers than do pension payments. In fact, the point is made that that is only 9 per cent of salary compared with pension payments of 12 1/2 per cent. But overriding that, in the area of Commonwealth and State public servants the contribution is of the order of 20 per cent. That demonstrates quite clearly the point that we have been making about the relative costs of benefits under a lump sum scheme as distinct from those under a pension scheme over a given period.

Quite apart from that, this report comes at a most useful time in the whole discussion of the problems of providing pension and retirement income benefits for Australians when we consider the Government's actions in this area in the last three months. We recall the mini-Budget in --

TALK.START.PARA: —It is reprehensible.
—It is reprehensible, as Senator Chaney says. In the mini-Budget in May we noted that the Government decided to apply a tax at the outrageous rates on lump sums payable upon retirement.
—Tut, tut!

—Senator Crowley tut tuts as usual about a matter which is of great concern to Australians. She is not interested in matters affecting South Australia, as evidenced by her actions in this place last night. Nor is she concerned about the retirement problems of Australian pensioners. But the point I make, Mr President, is that, in addition to the introduction of taxation on lump sum superannuation payments and an incomes test for the over 70s, the Government's latest announcement about the introduction of an assets test has left everybody in the community floundering with confusion because it has been inadequately represented and explained by the Minister for Social Security ( Senator Grimes). TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I want to make a couple of points on what is obviously a much needed report. I refer honourable senators to the definition of technological change on page xii of the report, which states:

Technological change is change which leads to new products (including services) or to new processes for producing existing products; technological change involves an impact on the nature of work (mediated through techniques of organisation and management), on the economy, and on society.

I would suggest that many unions have found to their members' detriment that effects on work by technological change are not always mediated by organisation or management techniques. Often rationalisation involving disemployment and de- skilling of workers has occurred along with, but not directly caused by, technological change. Technological change is sometimes used in fact as a smoke- screen to avert the wrath of unions. It is said: 'It is technical progress', et cetera. Therefore I think this definition is in error and I reserve the right to point out on behalf of the vast majority of Australian workers who are not managers that their jobs are not necessarily protected by well meaning management who will keep them on at any cost. Often the reverse is the case.

The second point I raise relates to the strong reference to retraining, education and, indirectly, income maintenance while workers are between jobs. It seems to me that that is another example of the public subsidising private enterprise and then having to apologise. Unfortunately, many people believe that government, paid for by the whole community, should never be allowed to act as an initiator of productive processes but act only as a safety net for private business when it needs it. Corporate interests just will not underwrite comprehensive retraining and they deride 'welfare' income maintenance programs. I believe it is time that these interests realise that if they want the insurance they have to be prepared to pay the premiums and to appreciate that centralised government planning has a primary role to play in modern industry. It works in advanced countries such as Japan and West Germany but for it to work in Australia the first thing we have to do is to remove that stigma of ' government spending', 'creeping socialism' or the like and we have to undertake comprehensive and long term programs orientated towards minimising social disruption because of technological change and other economic trends.

I commend the report to the Senate but I make the very valid point that those issues that I have raised are extremely important as far as the vast majority of Australians are concerned who are not management but are in fact those further down on that socio-economic scale, the workers of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply wish to draw the attention of honourable senators to one section in this excellent report headed 'Health and safety effects of new technology'. As has been said very often in this chamber, there is no way that I could possibly have grasped the contents of this book in the last day or so.
—Senator Messner does not seem to care.

—I thank Senator Bolkus for his comment. We will remind him later. We simply must continue to pay increasing attention to the health and safety dimensions of new technology. The document makes very good comment about the impacts of health and safety on technology. More importantly, it refers to the impact of technology on health and safety factors. The points that Senator Coleman alluded to apply also very much when we are talking about health and safety factors. The designs of jobs to accommodate technology very often mean increasingly boring and repetitive jobs. This has been a contributing factor to the increased number of injuries due to repetition of the same human movement. In particular, the most known example is that of tenosynovitis. I mention this not only because it is the most widely known, but also because it is a disease more often seen among women. That is not because men doing those jobs would not get the injury, it is because they do not do the jobs. In fact, there are some very nice studies already done that show that men who do the same amount of repetitive work would have exactly the same likelihood of getting tenosynovitis. Women do not get it more often than men because their arms are frailer, as I have had it put to me on one occasion. They get it more often because the cause of the injuries is the number of repeats of the same action. It is usually a woman's problem because it is in the work that women do that the most repetition happens. On one page of the report there is a very nice reference to the need to change the activities that contribute to a job. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Where a user's work involves a mix of activities such that it forms a meaningful and satisfying job, the perception of minor inadequacies in the ergonomics of the equipment or work place is likely to be minimised.

It is not only the perception that is minimised, but also the likelihood of unsafe or ill-making outcome that is minimised. There is now a lot of evidence that says that when a person's job involves four or five different pieces of work about which a person revolves there is much less likelihood of repetition injury happening. I turn now to paragraph 7.53 of the report. It states:

Clusters of miscarriages and birth deformities have been reported amongst pregnant women working with visual display units; such coincidences may not be significant and long term prospective studies, with appropriate controls, are the only ways in which the questions of causative links can be validly resolved.

While I agree that we need valid resolutions and proper research, I also feel that anything that could possibly be held as a causal connection with miscarriages or birth deformities ought to be treated with the greatest of suspicion. I do not think we need the hard evidence before we start building in super-safe measures. I do not think we need to have birth deformities and miscarriages if we can possibly prevent them. If it is discovered that there is not a causal connection between them and their work hazards-visual display units in this case-let us discover that later. In the meantime, let us build the safety requirements as a prevention, rather than say: 'Well, we have not discovered that there is a cause. We will make it safe after the event'. I would like to see a clear emphasis on safety beforehand and have the evidence gathered later.

The final point this chapter refers to is stress. I think there is much increasing evidence of the association of stress with the introduction of technology, not only because of the changes that are required to be made by workers, but also because of the increased rate of repetitive productive activities. I refer people to Charlie Chaplin's film Modern Times. I am not sure of the year in which it was made, but it was probably in the 1920s. If ever there was an excellent analysis of repetition injury some 60 years ago that we still seem not to have learnt it was Charlie Chaplin's film Modern Times. Perhaps if we put this report alongside his film, we will make some better judgments for the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: — I was not seeking in any way to disrupt what Senator Peter Rae was proposing to do because I think there is a lot of merit in his suggestion. I saw him bobbing and I thought I would dwell on what he had to say and follow his remarks. I am in the position of Senator Harradine in the sense that I received the report late yesterday and I have not had a chance to do it justice. However, some remarks ought to be made. This unquestionably important report deals with the most fundamental question that I am sure all parties in this chamber address themselves to. I refer to the question of full employment in a period of rapid and accelerating technological change. I must say, though, that the area of the report I find most disappointing is that area from page 152 through to page 157 concerning industrial relations. I think that this subject is an essential part in any consideration of employment and technological change, yet in a voluminous report it occupies, unfortunately, only five pages of analysis.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that the important question the Australian community, not just the Parliament, should address itself to in terms of technological change is the difference between change and progress. I do not accept-and indeed some of the remarks of other senators in a discussion of this report indicate that they do not either-that all change is necessarily progress and that all change is good. I think it is time for the community to assert what sorts of changes it wants in the interests of improving our quality of life. In terms of the industrial relations component of the debate, I think spokesmen from industry and academia as well as from the unions all predict that in the future machines will do, if not all of the work, most of the work. But none of us has reached the situation in which we can agree on the means by which we can make a transition from the type and nature of employment we have now to that future scenario. Nor is there an agreement or an understanding about what the time line might be.

I think following the Government's line of consensus decision making it is important that there be more discussion about adjusting to technological change in the work place. Unions are often painted in the position of being Luddites and of resisting change. But frequently the first time workers hear about technological innovation in the work place is when they are delegated to uncrate the new machines that often will replace or severely alter the nature of their work. There is little consultation about the introduction of technology. There is certainly very little ability for those workers to have a say and an input into the way in which that technology might best be used to provide work for all . The advantages of scientific progress through technology should be shared by all and not just by those who are able to buy the machines and who, as a consequence, throw others out of employment. A central matter in industrial relations is quite clearly a form of industrial democracy, a form of consultative process. Rather than the unions resisting the introduction of machines, which threaten employment and jobs in the future the change could occur smoothly on a consensus basis to the advantage of all employers and unions .

I have referred to paragraph 8.62 which appears at page 152 of the report and deals with industrial relations. It indicates that one of the major questions is that of redundancy. I would argue that redundancy is not the major question. Redundancy occurs only after the fait accompli of technological change. The question then is: At what cost to an employer can he disperse his workers into the general work force? It is not a question of whether the change being introduced is desirable or how it can best be managed to share the advantages between the employer and the work force.

We can look to comparable economies. I do not often accept that the Japanese economy is comparable to Australia's but at least workers looking forward to life long employment in the major areas of industry in Japan have security. Thus , industry in that country is able to embrace new technology more rapidly and easily. Workers in Australia, with a lack of job security, resist technological change because it threatens their futures. Until we answer the central question of how the advantages are to be shared through consultation we will have the stop-start progress which we have made in this area.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: -On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory I present two reports on proposals for variations on the plan of layout of the city plan of Canberra and its environs, the seventy-fifth series item 2, seventy-ninth series and the eightieth series dated August 1983. I seek leave to make a brief statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reports I have just tabled on the seventy-ninth series of variations to the city plan cover 12 variations and recommend the approval of work valued at $34.8m. The Committee, in considering these proposed variations, took evidence from several individuals and community groups as well as a member of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly during three days of public hearings. The Committee approves the variation at Kaleen to provide further residential development subject to the provision of a school crossing. The Committee believes that safe means must be provided for young children to cross streets on which a primary school is located. The Committee finds unacceptable the current practice of the National Capital Development Commission and the Department of Territories and Local Government of not always providing either a school crossing or an underpass at a major entry point to a primary school except in the few cases where a crossing would be unsafe.

SPEECH.PARA: Variation 7 is concerned with changes to roadways in Civic to provide a site for the proposed White Industries Ltd development of a hotel convention centre and offices. The Committee has made approval of this variation subject to the gazettal of Glebe Park simultaneously with the approval of the White Industries proposal. Regardless of whether the White Industries proposal gains approval, the Committee recommends that Glebe Park be gazetted as a public park before the end of 1983. The Committee also recommends the inclusion in the park of a number of mature trees which are currently in the road reservation. The Glebe Park area contains a number of mature elm trees over 100 years old which are an attractive and important part of our heritage. Their preservation must be ensured. The urgent need for adequate retail facilities in Tuggeranong and community facilities in Kaleen, which has resulted from poor planning in the past, has forced the Committee to approve arrangements which may prove to be unsatisfactory in the long term. The Committee is most dissatisfied with being placed in this situation.

In view of the lack of shopping facilities and other services, the Committee approves the road variations which will enable up to 14,000 square metres of retail space and 4,000 square metres of non-retail space at Erindale. In respect of this particular variation three members of the Committee have tabled what is in name a dissenting report but which in a very real sense approves of the road variation but has reservation about what should occur with the shopping site that is proposed.

The purpose of the Committee is to vary the city plan and the road arrangements which have been approved for variation are the same whatever the size of the shopping centre that it may finally be determined should be placed on the site. For a long time it was suggested that the site size should be 6,000 square metres but subsequently it was suggested, and the National Capital Development Commission has proposed, that it be 14,000 square metres. At the hearing we heard evidence from Mr Pead, who is the Chairman of the Canberra Commercial Development Authority, that it should be 24,000 square metres. There is no doubt whatever from the evidence that we heard that the impact of this site on the Wanniassa shopping centre will be quite severe. That shopping centre is too close to Erindale and it has been allowed to become too large for the area.

But there is not the slightest doubt that the people in the Tuggeranong Valley are presently deprived of shopping area. It appears that the small neighbourhood shopping areas in some of those suburbs should have been constructed much sooner than they have been. There is confusion about whether there will be a town centre in the area and, if there is, whether there will be retail space in it. It is this confusion about the future of retail space in the area that has caused us to raise in our dissenting report the question of whether the shopping area should be 14,000 square metres of retail space or whether it should be a staged development. We ask that the whole plan of the area be looked at as soon as possible. The difference in the two reports is that the one of the majority of the Committee suggests 14,000 square metres forthwith whereas the three of us who have dissented from that report have questioned whether that is the right amount of space at present.

As I have said, the roads which are to be varied are the same variations in any event. Comrie Street is a street which needs to be looked at again in terms of the nature of the development. It is very important that the construction of Wynn Street take into account the fact that children and students from the Erindale College will be frequently crossing it. The nature of the crossing should be so determined as to focus it in one place and minimise the danger. The other matter which we highlight in the report is the fact that any tavern in the shopping centre, which is very close to the Erindale College, should be at the farthest possible distance from the college. The important thing is to get on with the construction of shops in that area of Canberra as a matter of high priority.

To continue with the seventy-fifth series of variations, the previous Committee withheld approval for a new subdivision of 114 detached housing blocks in Giralang until a commitment was received for the construction of an access road linking the subdivision with the rest of the suburb. The Minister for Territories and Local Government (Mr Uren) has now agreed to the required access being included in the forward construction program and the Committee approves the variation at the cost of $1.6m.

The other report which is being tabled relates to the eightieth series of variations and concerns the access roads to the Canberra Technology Park at Bruce. In considering this the Committee noted the House of Assembly report and took evidence from the Department, the NCDC and Lend Lease Corporation Pty Ltd, and held public hearings on 14 August. The development is expected to attract high technology industry to the Australian Capital Territory, generating 300 jobs during the construction phase and providing 700 to 1,000 jobs on completion , with a flow-on of employment in support facilities outside the park. The Committee approves the variation. However, we were concerned at the continuing lack of environmental protection legislation in the Australian Capital Territory covering matters such as air and water pollution and occupational health and safety. The Committee recommends that the drafting of this legislation be given urgent priority.

In the debate this morning on the report entitled 'Technological Change and Employment', it was mentioned that we did not have the benefit of seeing that report. But it is clear from that report that the health and safety aspects of new technology need to be taken into account. The Committee requests that the legislation for the Australian Capital Territory be produced as soon as possible .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table funding guidelines for the Commonwealth Education Commissions for 1984 and seek leave to make a statement in connection with the guidelines.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In 1984 the Government will make available $3,363m for schools and tertiary education in December 1982 prices, which is in real terms an increase of $65m or 2 per cent over the 1983 allocation. The main thrust of the guidelines to the commissions on the allocation of this money is to introduce greater equity into Australia's education system as well as to address youth unemployment and the low participation rate of young people in post-compulsory education. The guidelines demonstrate the high priority the Government gives to education. Despite financial stringencies necessitated by the previous Administration's policies, the Government has allocated sufficient funds to allow a significant start to be made on all major policy commitments.

SPEECH.PARA: A major innovation will be a new program to encourage young people over the minimum school leaving age to further their education in schools and tertiary institutions. This will cost $71.6m in 1984. The greatest part of this money will be spent in the government school sector because it is in these schools where the problem of early leavers is greatest. However, considerable benefits will flow also to non-government schools from expenditure in such areas as curriculum development. The new program to encourage young people to participate in useful and fulfilling education activities will be the centrepiece of the overall framework of youth policies which are being developed by the Government. The program, to be known as the participation and equity program, will incorporate the existing school to work transition program from the beginning of 1984. The $71.6m allocated to the program will be shared between schools and technical and further education. The new program will have the twin objectives of increasing participation in education and introducing greater equity in the Government's overall provision for young people.

The Government wishes to achieve a situation where, by the end of this decade, most young people complete the equivalent of a full secondary education, either in school or in a TAFE institution, or in some combination of work and education . The guidelines give recognition to the fact that government schools educate the great majority of Australian children. The Government is obliged to ensure that government schools operate at high standards and are able to offer effective education for children from all backgrounds. However, special efforts have also been made to help meet the needs of non-government schools.

Under these guidelines about 2,000 non-government schools will receive an increase in their Commonwealth per capita grants in real terms in 1984. For 1985 and beyond the Commission has been asked to consult widely in the process of preparing a new scheme for the funding of non-government schools. Considerations of equity and financial limitations required that the funds for needy schools be found partly by some reallocation within the 1984 education Budget. Grants for 41 schools which are the least in need of government assistance will be reduced by 25 per cent next year. All of the schools which have had their funding reduced will have the capacity to continue to operate at levels well above average government school standards. Except in extraordinary circumstances and on the recommendation of the Commission, the Government will not wish to vary decisions on schools affected by this policy in 1984. Such circumstances would include dramatic changes in the school's situation since the data collection year such as difficulties caused by a natural disaster. Any school wishing to receive such consideration will have its finances and other circumstances thoroughly investigated by the Commission.

The Schools Commission's guidelines, in addition to the participation program, allow funds for a new Computer Education Program under which $18m will be provided for secondary schools over three years, starting with $6m in 1984. The guidelines also allow for the restoration of retrospective cost supplementation arrangements, thus enabling the return of orderly planning to education programs , and for a significant increase in capital funds for government schools.

Included among the programs are moves to improve educational outcomes for women and for those from disadvantaged backgrounds, including Aborigines. Within the capital allocations for government and non-government schools, $7m will be earmarked for schools serving Aboriginal communities. The funds for the integration of handicapped children in regular schools will be increased by 20 per cent in real terms while funds for ethnic schools and migrant education will be maintained in real terms.

The Curriculum Development Centre is to be reactivated within the Schools Commission and will provide support for, amongst other things, the development of community languages. At the tertiary level the guidelines provide for increased participation and greater equality of access. An additional $10m is being provided for at least an additional 3,000 places in higher education in 1984. In recommending the use of these funds the Commission is asked to seek to increase the participation of women and disadvantaged groups including Aborigines, migrants and the handicapped, especially those who live in outer metropolitan areas. Overall, the tertiary guidelines provide for an increase in expenditure of 1.5 per cent in real terms. Beyond this, the restoration of retrospective cost supplementation will make an important contribution to stability and rational planning in tertiary education.

The guidelines to the Commonwealth Schools Commission and the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission have demonstrated the Government's desire to increase equity in Australian education. I commend the guidelines as an expression of education policies which will benefit the majority of young Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.
In the Sydney Morning Herald of 10 October 1981, the following quotation from Senator Susan Ryan appeared:
It is with reluctance that I for one conclude . . . that the freedom to send one 's children to an independent school is bought at too high a price for the rest of society.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I raise a point of order.
—Of course, you are very sensitive about that, are you not?
—I seek to make a correction in relation to the quotation which has just been alleged by Senator Peter Baume.
—There is no point of order. If you have been misrepresented you may seek leave to make a personal explanation after Senator Peter Baume has concluded his comments.
—I will do so, Mr Deputy President.

—I have just quoted from the Sydney Morning Herald of 10 October 1981. What we are seeing today in the tabling of these guidelines is the beginning of a campaign to put that kind of ideology into effect. The guidelines represent the first half of the Australian Labor Party's education program for the coming year. The other half is contained in this week's Budget, and what a sorry program it shows. In the Budget allocations, allowances for students fall far behind the increases given in unemployment benefit. The incentives for education, to match the fine words of this Government, are not provided. The incentive to leave education in favour of unemployment is increased. The Budget has shown the low priority accorded by this Government to education, as contained in the guidelines. It is very important that both-these guidelines and the Budget-be brought down. They have done more to reduce confidence and to cast doubt upon the bona fides of this Government than have any of its many other punitive actions. The guidelines set out a litany of broken election promises in the area of education, broken promises which I will detail. They set out dishonoured assurances as to procedure and protection for those who are to be hurt by what is in them and they contain not very subtle threats about what some sectors of education can face. They are riddled with Senator Ryan's ideology. I have quoted already from the Book Review in the Sydney Morning Herald. The Australian Capital Territory branch of the Australian Labor Party, of which the honourable senator was a member--
—Is a member!

—Of which the honourable senator is a member, at its June 1982 conference, authorised an Australian Capital Territory education policy which included, at paragraph 10, its acceptance of the need for an integrated public schools system and set out-
—What happened to that resolution, Senator?

—I imagine that when the Australian Labor Party got into government it might have considered it politic to submerge it. But at the time it took government its policy in the Australian Capital Territory-the honourable senator's division-was to seek an integrated public schools system as contained in the policy document of her party and published for public discussion. No wonder there is concern. The Government has even started talking today about its goals in education no longer being equality of opportunity for Australians but equality of outcomes. I believe that many Australians would want to discuss this and would be concerned about it. Equality of opportunity is something all Australians seek but if the Government is seeking and demanding equality of outcomes it will have to penalise those who are able to achieve-because of their own effort, perhaps because of natural endowment of intelligence or whatever- outcomes which are not the equal of other people.
—Senator, the Minister agrees with you that that is the Government's policy.

—The Minister has agreed that that is its policy and that agreement should be out in the public arena. It is no longer equality of opportunity; it is now equality of outcomes. I believe that instructions have gone to her Department that it is now to talk about equality of outcomes whenever it communicates with the public.

SPEECH.PARA: As honourable senators would know, these guidelines have been greeted with dismay and criticism. They have not been well received. Looking first at the Schools Commission guidelines and then at the Tertiary Education Commission guidelines, we see that several facts are not brought out in them. First, it is fact that most government schools in Australia operate at better resource levels than do most non-government schools. That is fact. The poorer schools in Australia are not in the government sector. To argue that the government sector is being disadvantaged is simply to ignore the available facts. The neediest schools in Australia are non-government schools.

If we look at what happened during the seven years of Liberal Government we see that the greatest improvement in dollars per head spent on school children occurred in the government sector. The greatest numbers of dollars per head were spent in the government sector. This was certainly so in some school areas. Pupil-teacher ratios saw the greatest improvement in the government sector during these years. While the independent schools and the government sector were equivalent in what they were able to do, the Catholic sector of school education had the greatest needs. It has the greatest need to be reassured and protected. It cannot be reassured or protected by the guidelines. The guideline decisions and the Budget, if taken together, give an indication of what the Labor Party has done in education.

First, it has reduced its total education spending as a proportion of total government outlays by 0.3 per cent in real terms. It has reduced expenditure on all student assistance schemes by 2 per cent in real terms. It has reduced the assistance for tertiary students by 6 per cent in real terms. Because the means test has not kept up, it has reduced the eligibility for the tertiary education assistance scheme by about 0.8 per cent in real terms. It has reduced other living allowances under other awards by 4 to 5 per cent in real terms. It has reduced expenditure on the Aboriginal secondary grants scheme, the Aboriginal study grants scheme and the assistance for isolated children scheme. Those are three areas in particular need, and the value of those benefits has been reduced by 4 per cent in real terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are all real cuts.

—They are all real cuts. Under the Hon. Susan Ryan as Minister, there have been real cuts in the value of what is available to Australian students. I hope she is proud of what she has been able to do for education in this country. If we look at the gap between the unemployment benefit and TEAS, we have seen it widen-not narrow, widen-as a result of the Minister's first effort in her stewardship of the education resources of this country. The incentives to leave education and become unemployed are greater now than they were when the Minister took over. All the Labor Party rhetoric has stressed the importance of participation and access in education, but the reduction in education spending and in student assistance expenditure shows what a hollow exercise that has been.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, as I have said, the rhetoric has contained a litany of broken promises. Let me set out what the promises included. In higher education, Labor promised to provide post-doctoral fellowships for 300 scholars to boost the national research effort. That promise has not been honoured. It promised to increase progressively student assistance through the tertiary education assistance scheme-TEAS-until it equalled the single unemployment benefit and then to maintain the nexus. Not only has that promise not been honoured, but the gap has been widened. It promised to raise the TEAS means test until it equated with average weekly earnings. That promise has not been honored. The Labor Party promised to establish an emergency student loan scheme to replace our loan scheme. That promise has not been honoured.

In relation to schools, Labor promised to institute a new program for primary schools at a level of $9m per annum. It put a money level on it. That promise has not been honoured. It promised to provide an additional $37m in the first year of the Government for recurrent resources for government schools. That promise was not honoured. It promised to provide an additional $16m for needy non-government schools in the first year of its program. That promise has not been honoured. It promised to provide $24m over three years for computer education. It has not honoured that promise completely; it has provided a lesser amount. The Government now says it is going to provide $18m. Of course, it does that against the background that its own advisory body, the Commonwealth Schools Commission, has recommended the expenditure of $125m over four years as being essential for the satisfactory progress of an adequate computer program.

TALK.START.PARA: —And only $4.8m this year.

—Only $4.8m this year, another promise from which they have retreated and which they have dishonoured. The Labor Party promised to establish a revolving loan fund, with an initial contribution of $5m, to bring forward the construction of planned new non-government schools. That promise has not been honoured. In technical and further education it promised a special triennial program costing $30m to upgrade equipment and facilities for the latest technology and to stimulate employment in Australian manufacturing. That promise has not been honoured. Labor promised an immediate boost-what does the word ' immediate' mean? It means it will do something the moment it takes government-of $15m for capital and recurrent funds to the States. That promise has not been honoured. In the area of migrant education it promised $45 per capita grants for ethnic schools. That promise has not been honoured. It promised the provision of $3.68m per annum to cover the costs involved in transferring all eligible casual migrant teachers to permanent positions. It made a big deal about that but the promise has not been honoured.

SPEECH.PARA: Against that background, the Government has done certain things. It has decided to start to penalise, to jeopardise the existence of and to threaten certain areas within certain parts of the non-government school sector. It has moved now to break the percentage link which has inflated grants as costs rise. It has moved now to penalise 41 schools in total contradiction to the process which it promised, in the statement which Mr Hurford issued at the time Labor presented its election manifesto, would be followed. It might be worth going back and looking at what was said at that time. The document states:

If non government school authorities decide that the resource objective they seek to achieve over a responsible time period is a parity of resources with government schools, then Labor would welcome this declaration and contribute to its achievement.

That was the promise. The actuality is that the Government has abandoned the percentage link without that consultation and without the non-government schools having that opportunity. But the Government said more than that. I quote again:

A period of time will be required to allow the Schools Commission to determine the community standard and to allow schools, in the light of that determination, to make their decision. Funding at present levels will be maintained during this period.

The Government made a specific promise that it would not move to disadvantage schools until their community standard had been developed and until schools had had a chance to make their decision in the light of that community standard. That promise was issued before the election in order to win the votes of the gullible. It has been dishonoured by Senator Ryan and her Government in the guidelines they have brought down. Mr Hurford also said:
I do have to say at the moment--
That was February this year-
the assessment of what is a 'wealthy' school is totally inadequate . . . We do not currently have an accurate assessment.

Mr Hurford said that in an attempt to placate and convince those who felt they were under threat. We have a litany of broken promises which the guidelines and the Budget reveal. The Government can have little joy in what it promised and what it has put aside.

TALK.START.PARA: —He was the shadow Minister, wasn't he?

—He was the shadow Minister speaking for the Australian Labor Party. In penalising the 41 schools Labor has ended at one stroke the principle of a universal entitlement of every Australian child to a basic grant for his education. Included among those 41 schools we have, for example, a small school in St Kilda with 66 pupils which charges no fees. But that school has been judged as one of the richest 41 schools in Australia and has been included in the list of schools whose funds will be cut. The Minister has used a very blunt index in this respect. With the abandoning of the percentage linkage that determines funding, the Government has placed in jeopardy the future planning which every non-government system needs to make and at one stroke taken away the assurance of Government grants to help with the education of children in that system. Most non-government children are educated in poor Catholic schools. Even the poorest Catholic school can have no guarantee that its grants will inflate each year as costs go up. It will be dependent now upon an annual appropriation by government. Whilst this Government is prepared to index benefit after benefit in other areas, it has removed the index link which protected non-government schools, most of them Catholic systemic schools and most of them poor-schools which represented the poorest part of the education system in Australia. It would be very interesting to know why the Government moved so readily to dishonour so many of its election promises, why it moved so quickly to set aside the assurances it gave when it was going to the election.
—That is what you get for dealing with socialists who are secularists.

—I am grateful for my colleague's assistance. The guidelines for the Tertiary Education Commission were not well received within the tertiary sector. It is interesting to examine the criticisms which came from the higher education round table, from the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations and other groups which clearly, while welcoming some of the positive things contained in the guidelines, were concerned about some of the total inadequacies.

SPEECH.PARA: This Government preaches greater participation. If it wants greater participation in higher education it must pay for it. It has shown very little inclination to pay for it. The guidelines provide $10m extra for higher education. Senator Ryan has indicated that that will provide 3,000 extra places. Simple arithmetic will reveal that on a dollar per head basis it will provide just about half of the cost of maintaining a university or higher education place at the present time. The higher education round table has taken the Minister to task. This is not just an Opposition objection; it is an objection from within the sector about the inadequacy of that amount of money to meet the goal which the Minister herself has laid down in her guidelines. The Government simply is not providing enough resources to do the job. It is pointless the Minister talking about extra participation unless she and her Government put the resouces in place to make that a reality.

I ask honourable senators to recall the Government's assurances on equipment funding. The 1984 allocation of $70.7m for equipment funding is no higher than it was in 1982. It is all very well to talk about equipping institutions to cope with technological change, but it means that the rate of technological change in the work place is not being reflected, even in a modest way, in equipment funding for universities and colleges. The guidelines give no hint of the promised return to triennial grants for capital and equipment funding. The Australian Labor Party made the promise but again it has failed to deliver. Another question arises in relation to the tertiary education guidelines. Senator Ryan has placed great stress upon the need to take more disadvantaged groups into higher education, but few specific proposals have been made as to how to provide the groups with that access. We do not know whether the Minister, through the Commission, has simply given instructions to each institution that it is to take a certain number, as yet unspecified, of disadvantaged people. Is she proposing programs of affirmative action? Is she setting aside the principle of entry on merit? If so, let the Minister come out and say so.

I refer to another part of the guidelines. Included in those guidelines is a reduction of 25 per cent in the subsidy which is available for colleges and halls of residence. There is already a critical shortage of accommodation on campus. She is talking about increased participation; she is talking about participation being easier for those who have disadvantages, which includes those from remote areas. Why, then, is there a 25 per cent cut in accommodation?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is all rhetoric.

—It is all rhetoric. My colleague reminds me of another program which was cut. I refer to the in-service program for teacher training, which is funded through the Commission. That was cut by 40 per cent.

—It was cut-by $7m, a 40 per cent cut. What kind of educational priority did this represent, hidden behind the verbiage that the Government would put the matter under further study? It was a cut of 40 per cent in what has been a valuable program.

SPEECH.PARA: It seems that higher education will have to await the new 1985-87 triennium for any promised initiatives to appear in relation to broadened access or increased participation in higher education. We will have to look ahead to that triennium to pick up the things not included by Senator Ryan in these guidelines. I suggest that Senator Ryan read with care the Press release put out by FAUSA in which she is taken to task.

I finish by coming back to a comment which I made earlier, and that is that the guidelines have to be seen in conjunction with the Budget provision. I would like to quote from a comment by Helen Trinca in a recent edition of the Australian. In her higher education supplement she put the relationship quite succinctly. She said:

To be seen to be boosting participation is politically vital for a government which has made much of the need to adapt to changing technologies and employment shifts. But it will be buying that growth on the cheap unless it recognises that some institutions are already stretched to cope with increased demand.

More pressing still is the need to provide enough money for students to survive : If there is no increase in TEAS in the Budget, the Government's participation drive will become a hollow exercise indeed.

We know what happened to student assistance in the Budget; it was cut in real terms. When one takes together the Budget provisions for students and the guidelines provisions for schools and tertiary education, it is easy to see why that sector is plagued by uncertainty, by fear, by a sense of threat and by a great sense of disillusionment with this first offering by the Labor Government. The broken promises and the penalties involved in these guidelines are well understood throughout the community.

—I ask Senator Baume to listen. I am quite happy to defend and argue things that I have said. SPEECH.PARA: It is with reluctance that I for one conclude that the freedom to send one's children to an independent school is bought at too high a price for the rest of society.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Peter Baume has set out very clearly the promises of the Australian Labor Party in the election campaign, the standards that it was setting for education at the tertiary and secondary levels , and the sense of pent up anger it was trying to express towards the former Government. This statement on the guidelines for the secondary and tertiary sectors and the Budget which was announced this week, indicate that all of those promises have been forgotten; they are unfulfilled. Senator Baume set out very clearly that list of promises, all of which are now shattered. I want to concentrate on some particular aspects of the guidelines in a little more detail but, first of all, I note that the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs ( Senator Ryan), in her remarks in the Senate today, talked about the financial stringencies of the last Government harming education. This is a myth which is compounded by the financial stringency of the present Government as expressed in these guidelines and in the Budget announcements on education.

SPEECH.PARA: The increase in education spending for next year, in money terms, will be 11 per cent. Yet the year before, under the Fraser Government, the increase in spending was 13 per cent. The year before that the increase was 14 per cent. The Australian Financial Review, in its analysis of the Budget, carefully set out the contrast between the last two years of the Fraser Government, in terms of education spending, and this whimper of spending from the present Government. The increase, even though it is a small real increase, is less. There was a greater real increase during the last two years of the Fraser Government than there is under this ALP initiative. The Minister has the audacity to come into this chamber and introduce a statement about the so-called myth of the financial stringencies of the former Fraser Government. If there is to be some such accusation about the former Government, let it be clearly understood that there is greater financial stringency in the guidelines which have been brought before us today and in the Budget this week.

By this set of decisions in education the Government has pulled off a double offence. It has offended its own supporters. It has offended those who have already seen the dangers of the Labor Government; they have realised that they are under attack. Let me say something about the Government's supporters. The Teachers Federation, both nationally and in the States, contributed more money towards the ALP's election campaign than any other single group in Australia contributed to any political party. Where is the pay-off? The pay-off is not to be seen in these decisions. There is a small increase in education spending. Where is the fulfilment of the promises that the Australian Labor Party made to that major lobby in Australia, the teachers, through their left-wing national and state unions? Those supporters are disappointed. Members of the Institute of Teachers in South Australia came to see me last week and expressed their dismay at the decisions of the Government. For example, they highlighted the $7m direct cut to the professional development of teachers. The very people who supported the ALP in the last election have suffered a direct 40 per cent cut in terms of teachers' professional development. They know about it and it hurts. They are complaining about this Government that has made false promises and is not fulfilling promises. Of course, they have all the more confirmed the opposition of those who were not supporters of the Australian Labor Party in the last election campaign, those in the non-government schools and many in the technical and further education sector who knew they were under attack.

I see the guidelines as compounded rhetoric without substance. Participation is a major theme of the rhetoric, yet where is the evidence of it in the decisions that have been made? The tertiary education assistance scheme has been cut. Student allowances have suffered a real cut. Students are worse off after the Budget than they were before. Small increases have been allowed. The 5 per cent increase for TEAS, for example, is less than half the inflation rate. If TEAS were a means to greater participation, to allow more access to women, migrants and to those from families on low incomes, why has not the Government done something about the statements made by Labor spokesmen for years? The tertiary education assistance scheme has in fact suffered a real cut. At the same time, where is the emergency loans scheme that the ALP made a lot of noise about, particularly in the early part of this year? It was quick to abolish the idea of the loans scheme which the former Government was to introduce this year-a $50m increase in direct financial resources for tertiary education. That $50m has been denied to the students of Australia. Has any loans scheme been introduced by this Government? There is not one dollar. The Budget is totally silent about a loans scheme. Not only have student allowances suffered a real cut, but also no loans scheme has been introduced. Students are doubly worse off. All the rhetoric about participation, access to education and so on from Labor spokesmen is hollow. Whilst Labor spokesmen may have nice fancy phrases about women, migrants and Aborigines and those who come from poor families having access to tertiary education, there is no evidence at all in these guidelines that the Government has helped those students.

There is one exception, perhaps, and that is the much commended initiative to provide 100 Aboriginal teacher training places. That was a promise of the former Government. The ALP said: 'Me too. We will fulfil that one'. I commend it. The ALP has this small achievement but the guidelines are empty rhetoric. The supporters of the Government, just as much as its opponents, have noticed it. The Government has, by these guidelines, achieved a compounding of double losers . It has lost its opponents and it has lost its supporters.

I will say something directly about one of the initiatives that is supposed to increase participation in tertiary education. An amount of $10m has been allocated to allow 3,000 more students to enrol in tertiary education. This is set out at page 10 of the guidelines which state that the Government's immediate objective in higher education was to increase participation in higher education by providing for at least an additional 3,000 students in universities and colleges of advanced education in 1984 and that the additional $10m recurrent funds provided for this purpose would enable more staff to be employed. When the cost of a tertiary student place is more than $5,000 per student, how is it possible to fund an additional 3,000 students for $10m? There will be less than 2,000 students. Again, the rhetoric of the Government is found wanting. It claims that it will have funds for 3,000 when in fact the funds will provide for less than 2,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —That cost is average though.
—He does not understand that.

—I would like the Minister to demonstrate quite clearly how those students will be distributed between universities, colleges of advanced education and colleges of technical and further education and how, with such distribution, the Government can gain even an average cost that will allow 3,000 students. Until that is set out I, and I believe many commentators independently in educational circles, will distrust the rhetoric in that participation goal.

SPEECH.PARA: I will turn to some additional offences in the area of schools funding. Perhaps it is a minor point in the context of the whole of the guidelines but, with regard to the registration of new non-government schools, there is a retrospective provision that has been announced in attachment B of the guidelines, which I note the Minister did not refer to in her remarks. It is something that the Government would want to cover up and on which it would not want to allow wider public debate. That is, that for 4 1/2 months retrospectively any new non-government school will suffer lack of guarantee for Commonwealth support. If the Government is to introduce such provisions, why are they not dated 28 July, the date of the Government's statement? Is it not wrong for the Government to announce at the end of July a changed basis for the funding of new registered non-government schools that goes back 4 1/2 months? The new guidelines are to operate from the day of the Australian Labor Party election-the defeat day for non-government schools. What about those non- government schools that have gone through their planning processes, determined with advice from the Schools Commission the kind of funding that they would receive under the guidelines that were then in place and begun their school in March, April, May or June of this year only to find at the end of July that the rules are all changed and backdated to 5 March? I regard that as irresponsible of the Government and I plainly ask the Minister to put to the Government that the date of the operation of those new guidelines be from the date of announcement and not from the date of the last election.

Finally, I want to talk about the question of equity. That is another theme in the rhetoric of these guidelines. It has already been noted. It is established now that the ALP Government seeks equality of outcome, not equality of opportunity. It is quite unrepentant in saying: 'Yes, we are going to cut all the tall poppies. We will not be giving help to those who are above the national average or the standard outcome in education provisions. We will just not fund those that exceed our standard resource levels for Government schools'. In fact, these guidelines state that schools that exceed 95 per cent of the standard resources of Government schools will not be funded.

TALK.START.PARA: —Those schools all got very substantial grants. They got less than they got last year, not no grant.

—I am saying that the Minister's guidelines state that the policies set forth for the coming years will deny Commonwealth support to a school with resource levels that exceed 95 per cent of the standard government school resources. That is set out clearly in these guidelines. I believe that that is a misinterpretation of equity. I do not believe it to be a sound interpretation of equity that we have this lowest common denominator equality of outcomes whereby those schools that have helped themselves and have gained, from fees from participating families in those schools, a higher educational resource are completely denied assistance from the taxpayer, from the Commonwealth Government. I believe that there ought to be a basic grant to all students, be they in government or non-government schools. That is the principle which we established over many years: That all students would gain 20 per cent of the cost of a government school place; that the Government school place would receive, from the taxpayer, 100 per cent funding and a place at a school least in need, because of its high educational resource, would receive a basic grant of 20 per cent of the cost of a government school place. I believe that that is a view of equity which is more defendable than the new concepts of equity which this Government is trying to establish.

SPEECH.PARA: As a Liberal senator from South Australia, I will continue to urge that there be a basic grant for all students. We have always maintained that there be supplementary needs-based grants for government and non-government schools that will help the educational resources in those schools to be increased, be it by the disadvantaged schools program or by the category 2 and category 3 funding which existed in the past. So I directly question the notion of equity which is one of the themes of these guidelines and reject it as being a lowest common denominator interpretation which is offensive to me and which is not equity at all.

—Incidentally, did she write to the Sydney Morning Herald to disown it?
—Yes.
—Did it publish that?
—No.
—Would she care to disown the statement from the New South Wales Teachers Federation to which I have just referred?

—Thank you, Madam Deputy President. Incidentally, it does not have the support of the vast number of teachers in government schools throughout the length and breadth of Australia. What the Government is now attempting, by a back-handed method, is economic blackmail against the parents in Australia who desire to exercise that right. She has attempted this economic blackmail in ways that will not work, for example, by attempting to set Catholics against Anglicans. In fact, they considered that there would be a continuation of the nexus, which is essential to ensure that justice in education is done. I suggest that people, and I am one of them, who have not had a high profile on this matter will be stirred into action and will be prepared to take steps to ensure that the clear undertakings given prior to the previous election, the clear indication that there would be a continuance of the nexus grant as an essential component of justice, will be maintained. —My question is addressed to the Minister for Social Security. Can the Minister provide an estimate of the number of persons presently claiming pension benefits who will be adversely affected by the reintroduction of the assets test? Has the Minister seen the statement from the Leader of the Opposition that the Government's policy on the assets test is a discriminatory attack on those pensioners and other people soon to retire?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Jones asked about the number of pensioners presently claiming benefits who will be affected by the assets tests. We cannot be exact about the figure because, as there has been no assessment of assets held by pensioners since 1976, when the assets test was removed, it is difficult to estimate at the moment. Using the figures of people affected at that time, we do know that about 1.5 million pensioners out of about two million pensioners will not have any worries at all because they simply will not be affected. Approximately 170,000 pensioners will in fact be better off. This leaves about 340,000 pensioners who could suffer some drop in income. Most of them will suffer very little drop in income. I am not claiming to be exact in these figures because of the difficulties of assessment. Certainly, all those pensioners who put superannuation payments or the benefits they received on retirement into government bonds or, for instance, Telecom bonds, and who, like most people, declared that income, will in fact be better off because their notional income will be assessed at 10 per cent whereas in fact they will be receiving from 11 1/2 per cent to 12 1/2 per cent or more on that income.

ANSWER.PARA: The people who will be affected are those who have been encouraged to put their money into all sorts of contrived schemes, shonky investment trusts, and who do not have assessable income even though they, in fact, on any reasonable definition of the term, receive income. If any honourable senators question the burgeoning of those schemes in recent times, I refer them to the advertisements in the financial papers and in papers which have been directed at people with retirement incomes in recent years. The extent of this advertising is an indication of how widespread these operations are. Of course, the previous Government recognised this because at various times it attempted to do something about it. People have been exploiting the system to the disadvantage of pensioners on small fixed incomes, such as weekly superannuation payments, to the detriment of the taxpayers of this community and to the detriment of all pensioners because the capacity of governments to increase the standard rate of pension has been limited by the removal from the system of this amount of money. We hope that, once these people have been detected and once this practice is stopped, pensioners will be advantaged by the increased capacity of the Government to pay reasonable pensions.

Of course, one would expect the Leader of the Opposition to behave in the fashion in which he has behaved and to make the sorts of statements that he has made, as Senator Jones quite rightly points out. Most pensioners, as I have said , will not be affected by the change. I remind honourable senators that four previous conservative Ministers for Social Security, between 1961 and 1972, including Mr Sinclair, administered an assets test of the type we are reintroducing because they believed that it was a fair system and because they knew that the removal of the assets component from the means test would result in the sorts of problems we have had in recent years.

I note also that Mr Peacock complained that we are introducing uncertainty into the lives of people who are reliant on pensions. I remind honourable senators that Mr Peacock was a member of the Government which, in 1978, having promised to maintain twice-yearly indexation, in fact removed twice-yearly indexation. It was only after pressure from the Opposition at that time and pensioner organisations that that was restored. It was the same Government which, after a firm promise by Mr Fraser in 1977 that it would not touch the over-70s pension, in fact changed the over-70s pension. I suggest to honourable senators that the record of the previous Government as far as treating pensioners with consistency is concerned was not a good one, to say the least.

It is unfortunate that, because of statements by the Premier of Queensland and other uninformed or maliciously intending people, the present confusion has arisen. But that confusion is quickly dissipated. I know that most honourable senators opposite are aware of the necessity to introduce an assets element into the pensions means test in order to overcome the very real difficulties which have been recognised by people on both sides of this chamber for the last six years.

If Senator Messner believes that we should not introduce an assets test, unlike his predecessors in the portfolio from that side of the chamber, he should get up in his place and do something which he has not done in government or in opposition, namely, suggest what other methods could be used to overcome what is recognised in this community as a problem not only by the Government but also by the previous Government, by those involved in welfare, by the media and by anyone else who has any knowledge at all of the area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Leaving the Minister's rhetoric and bluster aside, will he address himself specifically to the question? Can he confirm the report in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald that at least 2,500 employees will be taken into the Department of Social Security and, I take it, the Department of Veterans' Affairs, in order to examine the assets requirements? As the Minister has already stated, no figures are available since 1976. Can he state more clearly exactly what numbers will be required? What will be the salary costs relating to those people? What is his firm estimate of revenue to be collected?

—The total estimate of expenditure in the next Budget from my recollection is $35m, which includes the whole of the establishment of the assets test. The total estimate of people needed in the first full year of operation, which includes temporary staff, because, as even Senator Messner would understand, we will need a fair number of temporary staff to establish the test, in the Department of Social Security-I will have to check it-initially is about 2,000 staff. Later that number will be reduced considerably. I will get the exact figures for Senator Messner. I have not got those figures at the moment. I said that I do not have a firm estimate of the amount of money which will be saved because one cannot make a firm estimate when one simply does not have the information. If Senator Messner is implying in his question that we should not introduce an assets test, that we should leave the situation as it is now, he should get up and say so. The newspaper reports of the Budget yesterday had no stories of the type which were stirred up by the unwise and wrong statements of people yesterday, but we became aware by Question Time yesterday that in fact some people were concerned.
