We had to get a question asked from our own side.

—Mr President, I take a point of order. The Minister is clearly debating the question. He is refusing to answer it. I ask that the Standing Orders be drawn to his attention and that he be given an opportunity to put facts before the Senate.
—Mr President--
—I ask Senator Grimes, in answering the question, to bear in mind standing order 100.
—Mr President, any time anyone answers a question in this place in a slightly aggressive way--

—I raise a further point of order. Mr President, while you were responding to my point of order the Minister continued to speak. I therefore wish to give you the opportunity to repeat what you said so that he can hear it.

—I think Senator Grimes did hear what I said. I asked him, in responding to the supplementary question asked by Senator Messner-I point out by way of interpolation that so far there have been only two questions and two supplementary questions from members of the Opposition, and Question Time has been going for about 17 minutes-to bear in mind standing order 100 in the rest of the answer.
—Thank you, Mr President. As the Opposition clearly does not want to hear any further answer, I will sit down.
—Can the Minister for Veterans' Affairs give a clear explanation of the assets which will be excluded from the assets and income tests on service pensions provided in the 1983-84 Budget?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no question that there is a great deal of confusion about Budget matters as they relate to service pensions. I repeat what Senator Grimes has said: As far as my Department is concerned, the Budget proposals apply only to service pensions. They do not apply, for example, to disability pensions or to totally and permanently incapacitated beneficiaries; they apply only to service pensions. There is probably a lack of understanding about this on the part of the Opposition because statements made by spokesmen from the other side and letters which have appeared in the newspapers indicate that statements I have made at Returned Services League congresses about the abuses taking place in the service pension area have been completely misinterpreted and confusion has followed accordingly.

ANSWER.PARA: I point out to the Senate, therefore, that a service pension is the age pension paid five years earlier to those who served in a theatre of war. It is just recognition for those who served in such a designation. It represents a five- year earlier payment of the age pension. It means something like $35,000 to service personnel and their spouses. I believe that is an adequate and just recognition of the Government's proposal to pay a pension to those servicemen who are eligible to receive it.

On today's values that $35,000 is a quite large sum of money. Service pensioners are also eligible to receive all the fringe benefits which are available. Those benefits vary from State to State. Consequently, $1,000 to $1, 500 in additional benefits is available to those who qualify for a service pension. The assets and income test will apply to people with substantial assets -I am talking about liquid assets. My Department has drawn my attention to the fact that hundreds of people with large superannuation payments of, say, $150, 000 and businessmen who have considerable assets, place their money in non- income earning accounts. They do not receive any income and therefore they can apply for and be awarded a service pension. On receipt of that pension they become eligible for the fringe benefits.

I draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that those fringe benefits apply to Telecom Australia charges, water rates, local government rates, travel costs and, in some cases, electricity and other fuel costs. In granting those concessions the authorities are forced to raise charges, which means that the unemployed, who do not receive any of those additional benefits, are consequently subsidising those people who are abusing the current service pension system. Questions on this matter have been asked of the Minister for Social Security. In my Department the growth in expenditure will be something like $600m in the next three years. Whilst I concede that the bulk of the applications for increases in the service pension area will be bona fide and will be accepted by the Department, even within the new arrangements arising out of the Budget, there will be a saving in my Department of in excess of $150m. A very limited number of casual employees will be appointed in the next year to service those applications.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is addressed to the Minister for Resources and Energy, follows the question I asked him earlier. In response he said that the Government used the best estimates available to it in arriving at a figure of about $120m revenue from the new excise on fuel oil and other matters. Are not the figures for 1982-83 available to the Government as they are available to the public? Do not those figures show that approximately 4,000 megalitres of fuel oil were sold in Australia last financial year? Even allowing for a further decline in the use of fuel oil, would not the usage of, say, 10 per cent less than that return the Government revenue of, say, $350m in a full year? Therefore, how can he say that the Government has used the best estimates available if he agrees that these figures are available from his Department and they show that substantially larger amounts of revenue will be raised?

—Figures are published. However, within those aggregate figures there are a number of important sub-components. For example, I think that just over 20 per cent of the fuel oil recently sold in Australia will be used for overseas bunkering. Whilst figures may be available, the degree of elasticity in consumption-the price elasticity of demand if honourable senators want a more jargonistic term-cannot be predicted with accuracy. Estimates were made of demand elasticity as a result of price changes. That is one of the factors which was incorporated in the information provided to the Government. As I stated earlier, challenges have been made to the accuracy of those estimates. The Government is examining those challenges and will, if necessary, make a statement in the near future.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Did the figures made available to the Government include an estimate of the loss of use of fuel oil due to companies being driven out of business by this new impost?
—I do not think there is any need to respond to a smart-Alick question like that.

—I ask the Minister for Industry and Commerce what the Government has done to honour the commitment made prior to the election regarding increased funding for secondary industry through the Commonwealth Development Bank of Australia and the Australian Industry Development Corporation, particularly in the area of increased grants for industrial research and development.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Budget clearly indicates the Government's positive approach to industry assistance, to which Senator Coleman's question is directed. In replying to specific aspects of her question I will mention three matters. First of all, the Government has freed from Australian Loan Council control, Commonwealth Development Bank and Australian Industry Development Corporation borrowings. It has also agreed to double the gearing ratio of the AIDC and has decided to guarantee its borrowings. It has relaxed restrictions on the use of capital for equity finance and has increased the paid-up capital by 20 per cent by allocating a sum of $12.5m in the Budget, increasing the capital of the AIDC to $75m. It is the Government's belief that these decisions will significantly increase the financial capacity of the Commonwealth Development Bank and the AIDC, in particular, to help industry.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Coleman asked about the extension of aid to industrial research and development. May I add that funding for industrial research and development has been increased by over 35 per cent to $71.6m. Significant funding has also been allocated for training programs to improve the skills of the work force and we believe that this, coupled with other announcements in the Budget context, provides a very favourable environment for industry in a period of recovery.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: VANDALISM IN NATIONAL PARKS OF TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment is aware of the mindless vandalism by groups of morons who pose as self-appointed dam protesters in South West Tasmania. —I share the concern expressed by Senator Chipp in his question. The South West Tasmanian wilderness region is an area which not only all Tasmanians but also all Australians and, indeed, the world, have very good reasons to preserve, to protect and to look after. I can only express my disappointment that the Tasmanian State Government has not seen fit to act in the interests of all Tasmanians and, indeed, all Australians in this matter. With regard to the specific steps that Senator Chipp has suggested that the Federal Government undertake, I will refer those to the responsible Minister, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Barry Cohen. —I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate: What is the Government doing in the Budget to meet its election promise to create jobs for unemployed Australians?

—As Senator McIntosh is probably aware, if he has examined the Budget Speech in some detail, a number of initiatives have been taken in respect of unemployment. The first thing is that, as the Senate is well aware, we have provided additional unemployment relief. A wide range of measures has been put in place. The Government has also introduced the community employment program, something which the previous Government declined to do. That will create a significant number of jobs in the community. Special measures have been taken in respect of particular areas where unemployment is highest; for example, cities such as Wollongong and Whyalla. Senator McIntosh will be aware that the Government is not predicting in any euphoric way an immediate possibility of reducing the number of unemployed. However, the Government is encouraged by present trends in the unemployment figures, particularly present trends in the creation of jobs. It is hoped that in the context of the recovery that process will proceed and accelerate. A number of industry assistance measures which were referred to earlier at Question Time will, it is hoped, assist with that process and the process of industry recovery. The Government is taking a wide variety of measures in an environment in which it is not claiming that a dramatic impact can be made on the reduction of unemployment in the next 12 months. A number of measures in the Budget are addressed to laying the basis for a vast improvement in the employment figures in this country.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security and relates to the Government's announced assets test on pensions. I ask whether the Minister recalls saying on Budget night:

QUESTION.PARA: The final details of how the new test will work in practice will be settled after I have consulted with pensioner organisations.

If so, why did he make a statement yesterday committing the Government to a position in advance of consultations with pensioner groups, thereby presenting them with a fait accompli? How can the Minister explain the conflict either between him and the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, or between their departments , over the gain to revenue from the introduction of the assets test?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am unaware of the conflict that Senator Crichton-Browne mentioned in the latter part of his question. In relation to the former part of the question, I said in the statement which I produced in this place and I have said since, that we will consult with pensioner organisations about the details- I have since taken action to do so- for instance, on what sorts of modifications of things may be excluded. I have spoken briefly with the representatives of the Australian Democrats. Indeed, I am willing to speak even with members of the Opposition about this matter. We have a couple of months in which to discuss this matter and I will do so. I announced and the Treasurer announced that we were reverting to an assets test of the type that existed before 1976 and that we would have the sorts of exemptions in that assets test that existed then. The aim of this exercise is not to affect the ordinary pensioner; it will not affect the ordinary pensioner. The aim of the exercise is to affect those who have been circumventing the income test and, in fact, going against the intent of the social services legislation in this country.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware that every time a change of this type is made to ensure a more adequate redistribution of the wealth in this community and to ensure that people more adequately pay their fair share for the social good of this country, people like Senator Crichton-Browne, as he did in the tax evasion and tax avoidance legislation, oppose that change every time. But some of us in this place happen to believe that it is part of the duty of this Parliament and of this Government to ensure that the ordinary wage earners and workers in this community who go through their lives paying their taxes because they have to do so and because it is their duty to do so, do not suffer. We believe that when they retire and declare their incomes and have that income included in the income test for pension purposes because that is the right thing to do and because they have to do it, they should not suffer at the hands of those who avoid the taxation system and the means testing system of pensions. We will stand by that. We will take steps to ensure that the system is fair, despite the efforts of people like Senator Crichton-Browne.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I will save my response to that answer for another time. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Gietzelt, referred to liquid assets only. I ask Senator Grimes: Is that the position? Will the assets test be on liquid assets only?

—I refer Senator Crichton-Browne to my statement and the statement made by the Treasurer. The problem is, as Senator Crichton-Browne knows, that people manage to place their assets and their wealth in the sorts of asset holdings which, under our system, could not be considered income whereas, under any reasonable definition, they are income. It is those people who do this deliberately to avoid the incomes test at whom we are aiming. I know that Senator Crichton-Browne thinks that is fair enough. I know he thinks it is fair enough in the taxation system. I know he thinks it is fair enough in the social security system. That happens not to be the belief of the Government or the belief of any reasonable thinking person in this community.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. In view of the Government's decision to introduce an assets test for pensioners and to income test those people over the age of 70, will the Minister explain why the Government has decided not to withdraw the family allowance and dependant tax rebates from well-off families?

—Senator Bolkus is aware that this question is a lively issue of debate in Australia and was especially so when Senator Chaney was Minister for Social Security, as I recall. Both the family allowances and spouse rebates are forms of assistance which recognise the extra cost of dependants at all income levels. Removing the entitlement from middle and higher income families would effectively mean a tax increase for families with dependants as against single taxpayers and working couples without children. The Government believes that the burden should be shared as equitably as possible. It has therefore decided to make no change to the family allowance or dependant rebates at this stage. Indeed, rather than reduce family assistance for middle and other income families, we have increased assistance for lower income families with children. I do not, perhaps, need to go to the details of those increases; they are available in the Budget context.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY: GOVERNMENT SCHOOL FUNDING

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: PASSENGER MOTOR VEHICLES: LOCAL CONTENT PLAN

TALK.START.PARA: —My question, which is directed to the Minister for Industry and Commerce, concerns the Federal Government's local content plan which applies to passenger motor vehicles and allegations that certain manufacturers are substituting light commercial vehicles for passenger vehicles to escape the local content requirements. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

A number of factors might be said to be eroding local content plans, including transfer pricing, which the Government is examining at the moment, and the penetration of light commercial vehicles. In trying to reach conclusions regarding this matter, the Government has a wide range of interests to consult. In the motor car industry, the interests which have to be consulted are extremely diverse in their views. TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs give a categorical assurance that no poorer non-government schools will be worse off in the future under the socialist Labor Government than they would have been under the formula existing up to now?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume that the honourable senator's question is addressed--
—Are you not socialists? Are you ashamed of yourselves?
—If we are democratic socialists, you are national socialists.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr President. The expression ' socialist' is embraced by some members of the Opposition and not by others. But the expression 'national socialist' is not acceptable. I believe that it is an unparliamentary accusation for Senator Grimes to have made to Senator Lajovic. I ask him to withdraw it.
—If the accusation was made, I ask the Minister to withdraw it.
—Mr President, interjections are disorderly. I merely responded to one with one. If the gentleman is offended by his past, I withdraw.
—I ask the Minister to withdraw.
—I withdraw, Mr President.

—I understand that the honourable senator's question was whether the poorer non-government schools are better off under the present formula for funding them than they would have been under the percentage link. The answer to that is yes. In the education guidelines we have provided for a 3 per cent real increase for category 3 schools. On the information that I had available to me at the time when I drew up the Budget submission, that was more than would have been available under the percentage link formula.

ANSWER.PARA: I add that the redistribution which the education guidelines have achieved demonstrates a real concern-I assure the honourable senator that it will be a continuing concern-to improve the standards of the poorer non-government schools . We recognise that there are about 2,200 non-government schools in Australia and about 2,000 of those-the vast majority-are in category 3. We are very supportive of the kinds of education services that those schools provide. They are in the poorer parts of our cities and country areas. By and large they take children from a very wide range of backgrounds. In the inner city areas, for example, Catholic parish schools have a very high percentage of newly arrived migrant children whose parents are very poor and often unemployed.

We are very supportive of the work of the category 3 schools and the education that they make available to the poorer section of the community. Of course, they are not only doing it now; they have a long history of contributing such education services in this country. Indeed, I personally have benefited from them. So I think, if the honourable senator is seeking assurances, that I can certainly give an assurance that we intend to continue to make funding arrangements which will allow the category 3 schools-that is, the poorer independent schools in this country-to improve the standard of education that they are able to offer to the children in their care.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. In view of some confusion evident in today's Canberra Times, which mistakenly equates 'affirmative action' with 'positive discrimination', can the Minister please explain the policy of the Government and the steps which are being taken towards achieving equal opportunity in both the Public Service and private enterprise?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is always grateful for newspaper coverage that draws attention to its more progressive policies. However, I must say that I find myself increasingly frustrated by the inability of reporters to distinguish between positive discrimination, which is not the policy of the Government, and affirmative action, which is. The Canberra Times story to which Senator Giles's question refers is to some extent a misrepresentation of the statement I made to that newspaper yesterday. I informed the Canberra Times that the Government is preparing an affirmative action Green Paper-a discussion paper-which will be published shortly and be available for public comment before we proceed to any legislation. However, in the meantime, interim affirmative action can be introduced by administrative arrangements within Public Service departments. I point out, of course, that it is not entirely new in that a policy of equal opportunity has operated within the Commonwealth Public Service for some time. Unfortunately, this policy has not been very effective.

ANSWER.PARA: I draw the attention of Senator Giles and the Senate to the current employment structure as it affects women within the Commonwealth Public Service. In the First Division, which is the highest division, there are no women. In the Second Division only 2.1 per cent of officers are women. In the Third Division 24.8 per cent of officers are women. In the Fourth Division-the lowest division-49.8 per cent of officers are women. I think that presents a picture of what we call structural discrimination. In order to overcome that one needs positive policies -training opportunities and work experience opportunities-so that the talents and qualifications that reside in female officers within the Commonwealth Public Service can be rewarded by promotion as indeed they are in the case of men.

Affirmative action means that there will be an introduction of programs to overcome the hidden and systemic discrimination embedded in apparently neutral Public Service practices and procedures, such as working conditions which are established to suit male life patterns, or selection criteria that can be more easily attained by men. Affirmative action consists of a series of programs and changes so as to counter this type of discrimination. It covers a wide range of activities, from ensuring that selection criteria are directly related to the job to be performed to such measures as ensuring that training sessions are scheduled at times when women can attend them and special career counselling and training for women. They are aimed at ensuring equality of opportunity at the point of selection.

I would like to make something very clear. Selection under affirmative action will continue to be on merit. This is, of course, in accord with the provisions of the Public Service Act and is guaranteed by the promotions appeals system. My own Department has begun the formulation of an affirmative action plan. However, all promotions in the Department have been, and will continue to be, on the basis of merit.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister to table the document from which she has quoted.
—Yes. I am delighted to give you more detail.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs. Following adjustments to the tertiary education allowances scheme and unemployment benefit levels in the Budget, the gap between the two has widened, causing additional disincentives for further education. I ask the Minister how the widening gap between TEAS allowances and the unemployment benefit will help increase the participation of young Australians in tertiary education.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government has announced a number of measures which will increase participation in tertiary education. One of them was an increase-a modest increase, I admit-in the allowances available under the TEAS scheme. I should point out to the honourable senator, though, that we have not only increased the level of allowances but also liberalised the family means test so that several thousand more students will become eligible for TEAS at the increased level than has been the case up until now. I also draw the honourable senator's attention to the extra $10m which should achieve an increase of 3,000 student places in tertiary education. Perhaps more importantly-this may have escaped the attention of some honourable senators-the secondary allowances scheme for poor families who have children who wish to complete the last two years of secondary schooling has been increased by 20 per cent. Clearly, that will have a direct effect on participation rates in tertiary education.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the fundamental problems-indeed, I have gone so far as to call it a crisis-in education in this country is that only one-third of young people are completing their secondary education as compared with up to 90 per cent in countries such as Canada, Japan and countries in Western Europe. One of the reasons why so many young people, particularly young people from poorer families , are leaving school before they finish secondary education and thus not qualifying for the next stage of tertiary education is that their families, in this time of extraordinary economic hardship, are unable to support them at school. We have given a higher priority to making a greater increase in the secondary allowances than to making--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not what my question was about.

—There is a connection. I think Senator Watson asked how this was going to achieve increased participation in tertiary education. My answer to that is that there is a range of measures which should enable a higher participation rate in tertiary education. Also, the Government has announced a major overhaul of youth income support schemes, including TEAS, which will start with an Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development review in November of youth income and employment training programs. It will be followed by what I believe will be a much more effective development of youth income support, including TEAS, which will lead to drastically increased participation not only in secondary and tertiary education but also in work force training.

—I address my question to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. What is meant by 'assets and income' in relation to service pensioners? What guidelines will the average service pensioner be affected by?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hearn asked me a question about the guidelines which will determine how the service pension will be affected by the Budget proposals. I indicate, firstly, that the average service pensioner has nothing to fear from the proposals in this Budget, nor has an applicant for a service pension when he or she reaches the age of 60. In fact, the proposed assets and income test- generally, it is referred to as the means test-is very generous. The distortions and anomalies that existed in the 1976 legislation have been removed by this Government. For a start, it will exclude from the valuation of a service pensioner's assets the service pensioner's home or principal place of residence. It does not matter whether its value is $50,000 or $500,000. The Government will exclude from valuation a car which is used by the service pensioner, whether it is a Ford or a Jaguar. We will exclude a pleasure boat, jewellery worn by the service pensioner and a caravan owned by the service pensioner. All personal effects and all works of art will be excluded. I want to make that point clear because questions were asked about liquid assets. None of those possessions to which I have referred will be taken into account in the assets test.

ANSWER.PARA: After the exclusion of all those assets to which I have referred, married service pensioners can have $28,500 worth of assets before the test starts to apply. That means that they will not lose one cent of their pension unless they have more than $28,500 invested in a bank, a building society, shares or the like. Even people who have very substantial assets above these levels will continue to receive some part of the service pension. QUESTION.PARA: Family allowances and spouse rebates are primarily tax measures rather than welfare measures.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Martin's question raises some rather complex matters of economic analysis. The important distinction to discuss is that between direct payments and tax rebates. It is my view, and I think it is the view of anyone who has taken an interest in the welfare system, that the cost to government of paying a direct payment-for example, a family allowance-has the same overall effect on that government's revenue position as the cost of allowing a tax rebate or a tax deduction. Up till now, that same effect has not been widely recognised in public debate on this matter, so we have heard the point of view that family allowances are a burden on the taxpayer and we should start means testing them because they are a direct payment, but tax rebates for various purposes are not a burden on the taxpayer. Of course, that is a false distinction. In the end either a rebate or a family allowance is revenue forgone so far as the Government is concerned. As we are moving towards a more equitable and effective way of assisting people who have dependants, we need to be very clear about that. I think the note to which Senator Martin referred does make the point that both rebates and family allowances amount to revenue forgone.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I take the point at the conclusion of Senator Martin's question that a very clear advantage of the family allowance payment over the tax rebate as a form of assistance to parents with children is that family allowances are paid directly to the mother. For that reason, the Government strongly supports the family allowance system and ways of strengthening payments to people with dependent children are currently under review. It is certainly our intention to make payments in this area of assistance to those with dependants as direct and as effective as possible, given the fairly complicated welfare and taxation arrangements that we have for doing it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that Senator Ryan said that a direct payment has the same effect as a tax rebate, is she therefore saying that a spouse rebate is a payment to a husband for having a dependent wife? How does that square with Senator Button's statement in his answer that the Government believes that the burden of dependants should be shared equitably?

—I think it does square with Senator Button's statement. When I said that the payment of a family allowance has the same effect as the provision of a tax rebate, I meant the same effect on revenue. Obviously it does not necessarily have the same effect on the recipients of those benefits. What we can be clear about with regard to the family allowance is that it is paid directly to the person, most often the mother, with the care of the children. Of course governments cannot interfere with what happens within family budgets and so I suppose we do not know, in the case of individual families, who in effect is the direct recipient of the dependent spouse rebate. So I would not quibble with Senator Martin that the effects may be different as far as individual families are concerned, but I simply repeat that the Government accepts that having dependants is an economic burden and that there should be some recognition of this in the way in which we distribute welfare and taxation benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In the past, members of parliament and the public have become aware of what the government's legislation program in any period of sittings is only when Bills are introduced. SPEECH.PARA: These will be the first full length sittings since the Government was elected and it provides the first opportunity to embark on a full range of economic and social reforms, to put our commitments into effect and to cope with problems we find before us-not, of course, that we have wasted any opportunities up to now. During the short autumn sittings we passed legislation to establish the community employment program, a demonstration of our first priority-to put Australia back to work. We also took the opportunity to institute a number of priority welfare and taxation reforms, to protect the South West Tasmanian Wilderness and to establish the Economic Planning Advisory Council and the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Legislation was introduced in fulfilment of major constitutional and legal reform priorities and debate is being resumed on those matters early in these sittings. I should like now to outline briefly the Government's legislation program in the period of sittings ahead.
Economic and Industrial Development

The Government will introduce legislation which is proposed for passage in the sittings to: Implement the recent decisions on the steel industry; give the Australian Industry Development Corporation a greater role in financing industry in Australia; implement various bounty decisions announced recently; reform the operation of various primary industry assistance and inspection arrangements, particularly in the dairy products and meat areas, and implement existing export inspection cost recovery policy; implement decisions on a review of the industrial research and development incentive scheme; and enable the period for which temporary assistance may be granted to an industry to be extended.

Depending on resources, it is hoped that legislation will also be introduced affecting the regulatory environment within which business operates; that is, amendments to the Insurance Act and the Life Insurance Act to improve financial standards, for passage; new legislation governing cheques and bills of exchange; and companies and securities legislation to revise the co-operative scheme in the light of experience and to implement decisions on a centralised scrip and accounting system and the futures industry.
Consumer Protection
Legislation will be introduced to establish the Prices Surveillance Authority. Other consumer affairs legislation is also under consideration.
Industrial Relations

A Bill amending the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to implement reforms already announced, including in relation to a complementary Commonwealth-State industrial relations system, will be introduced for passage. In addition, legislation to give effect to our commitments in the public sector industrial area will be developed and introduced if time permits.
Welfare and Community Development

Major pieces of legislation in the area of welfare and community development for introduction and passage will include: Bills to establish Medicare and to implement other Budget health decisions and other measures in the health area; Bills to establish the new first home ownership assistance scheme and legislation associated with the Government's decision to retain the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation; a package of education Bills implementing our decisions on schools and tertiary funding and making technical changes to the student assistance legislation; and major social security and repatriation Bills largely to implement Budget decisions.
Electoral Matters
Bills to implement our decisions on electoral reform, following the Joint Select Committee report, will be introduced later in the sittings.
Constitutional and Law Reform

As foreshadowed by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans), the Government plans to put referendum Bills through the Parliament to enable a referendum in February 1984. In addition, we propose that the family law, freedom of information, archives, ombudsman and sex discrimination Bills introduced last sitting will proceed. New legislation implementing various priority law reform commitments will include: Legislation to establish an independent director of public prosecutions; following the recent conference in the Senate chamber, revised proposals in relation to investigating organised crime; a revision to the Family Law Act in relation to legal aid costs, as announced in the Budget; legislation to provide for a new scheme for transfer of prisoners between States ; and legislation to implement aspects of the Australian Law Reform Commission's report on lands acquisition and compensation, which will be for inroduction only .

If time permits major human rights legislation also will be introduced, as will a new criminal investigation Bill. Depending on the progress of discussions with the States, an 'Australia Bill' will be introduced to end the residual colonial links with Britain. A uniform defamation Bill will be introduced as an 'exposure draft' to enable public comment. The customary Statute Law (Miscellaneous Provisions) Bill will also be put forward in due course.
Migration and Citizenship
The Migration Amendment Bill which is already before the Parliament will be taken further and citizenship legislation will be introduced to remove anomalous and discriminatory provisions.
Financial Measures

In addition to the appropriation Bills and taxation Bills introduced on Budget night, we will be introducing, for passage, normal States grants legislation and further income tax legislation to implement decisions from the Budget and the May statement, including in relation to superannuation and tax avoidance initiatives. Other Bills for passage will be introduced to implement Budget revenue decisions relating to broadcasting and television licence fees, customs and excise tariffs, and Budget decisions on the petroleum freight subsidy.
External Relations

Bills will be introduced for passage to fulfil our commitment to further Australia's contribution to the International Development Association, the Asian Development Bank and the International Monetary Fund. Legislation to implement the proposed Torres Strait treaty may also be ready for introduction. An Income Tax (International Agreements) Bill will be put forward to implement various agreements signed recently.
Other Measures

Other measures proposed for passage include: New radio communications legislation; amendments to enable the interstate commission to commence operations; and amendments to the Public Service Act to enable the operation of the community employment program in the Commonwealth Public Service.

Other legislation which may be introduced and proceeded with if time permits includes: Bills to improve the operations of the Australian National Line and Australian National Railways; legislation to restore the courier service of Australia Post and to make other amendments in the postal law; and a Bill to implement, through an amendment to the Patents Act, our accession to the Budapest treaty.

DEBATE.TITLE: UKRAINIAN PUBLIC GROUP TO PROMOTE THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE HELSINKI ACCORDS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate requests the Australian Government to convey to the Government of the USSR its deep concern at the repeated harassment of the 'Ukrainian Public Group to Promote the Implementation of the Helsinki Accords'.

On 1 August 1975, 35 countries signed the Final Act of the Conference on Security and Co-operation in Europe which has been described as the Helsinki Accords. The signatories were the heads of governments of 35 European countries including the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, the United States of America and Canada. The alleged achievements of the signing of the Accords were that the Soviet Union gained recognition of post-World War II boundaries in Europe and, in return, the West gained Soviet acceptance of provisions guaranteeing basic human rights and freedom and the rights of national groups to self-determination . Apart from these exclusive guarantees of human rights, provision was made for the monitoring and review of compliance with the guarantees in the Accords. In response to this, various groups were formed throughout the USSR, in the Ukraine , Lithuania, Georgia and Armenia, and indeed in Moscow itself. The principal aim of these groups was to ensure that the implementation of the Helsinki Accords was in fact honoured.

On 9 November 1976 the Ukrainian Public Group to Promote the Implementation of the Helsinki Accords, the body with which this motion is concerned, was founded in Kiev with 10 founding members. All of those 10 founding members were acquainted with Soviet understanding of human rights to the extent that between them they had spent a total of 63 years in different Soviet prisons, concentration camps, psychiatric institutions and hospitals. Despite this, the Group constituted itself openly and publicly announced its membership, aims, demands and principles, thus becoming a public focal point for Ukrainians previously united by personal ties, suffering and common goals. The Group was fully aware that the Helsinki Accords did not in fact represent a document superior to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and other similar international pacts. However, it was the most recent humanitarian document of a legal nature at that time containing provisions that stood to be taken as binding. Therefore, the Group was determined, according to its founding document , to:
Inform the governments of the participating states and world community of violation in Ukraine of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the humanitarian provisions of the Helsinki Accords.
Furthermore, the document stated:

We realise that according to the treaty of December 27 1922, forming the Soviet Union, all international agreements, signed by the government of the Soviet Union, also encompass Ukraine. It follows therefore, that the Declaration of Human Rights as well as the Declaration of Principles, on which the signatory nations of the Helsinki Conference are to base their relations, are in effect also in Ukraine.

At the same time the Group realised that the signing of the Helsinki Accords had recognised the Soviet post-war boundaries in return for what it considered to be insincere promises on human rights by the Soviet Union. That the Group was correct has been clearly illustrated by the harassment that it has endured from its formation to the present day. Of the original 10 members, all but two have been arrested on charges of anti-Soviet agitation and propaganda and forced to serve long sentences in Soviet prison camps, followed by years in exile. It was Soviet intolerance of the Group's activities as a body, acting in accordance with the Helsinki Accords as monitors of Soviet compliance with guarantees on human rights, which led to their incarceration. Documents sent to the Soviet- controlled Ukraine Government proposing that the Ukrainian Helsinki Group be recognised were officially ignored. The only response received was repeated harassment of members followed by imprisonment, exile and banishment. By 1980, of 37 members of the Group, 25 were imprisoned, one had committed suicide, six had been banished, two were in exile and one was in a psychiatric hospital.

I do not know whether honourable senators saw the Four Corners program about the treatment of the political inmates of psychiatric hospitals in the Soviet Union. If not, it is well worth having a look at the program. If any honourable senator wants a copy of the transcript that, too, is available from the Library. The statistics that I have just mentioned do not take into account the regular visits by KGB officers to the members' homes, the continued interrogation and other forms of harassment. Undoubtedly the fate of the 10 founding members was intended to deter other human rights activists from joining the Group. The courage of those who disregarded these obvious harassments and continued in the same vein as the founding members indicates the extent to which man is prepared to fight for basic human rights.

The death of six million Ukrainians in the artificial famine of 1932-33, the continued suppression of the facts surrounding that famine, the Russification of Ukrainian institutions, the suppression of dominant religious groups such as the Ukrainian Catholic Church and the Ukrainian Orthodox Church, and the fact that 50 per cent of political prisoners in the Soviet Union are Ukrainian are evidence of the sufferings of the Ukrainian people under their Soviet controlled Government. Two of the members of the Ukrainian Helsinki Group are of special interest to Ukrainian Australians as both have relatives in Australia. One, Oskana Meshko, has spent eight years in psychiatric hospitals, has spent terms in labour camps and, at the age of 77, is serving a term of five years exile in the Khabarovsk Krai. The other, Yuri Shukhevych, was arrested in 1948 at the age of 14, his crime being that he was the son of a general of the Ukrainian partisan army which opposed occupation of the Ukraine by both the Third Reich and the Soviets. Having served 10 years, he was arrested again for failing to denounce his father and in 1972 he was sentenced to a further 14 years for anti- Soviet propaganda. In other words, he has spent all those years since the age of 14 incarcerated by the Soviet Union. Still in prison 35 years later and now blind, this man who has relatives in Australia, epitomises the suffering and tragedy of the Ukrainian nation and the ideals that led to the formation of the Ukrainian Helsinki Group.

Much public attention has been drawn to the treatment of Yuri Orlov of the Moscow branch of the Helsinki Accords Group. His treatment led Valentin Turkin, Chairman of the Amnesty International Moscow Group, to say:
I am ashamed of a country in which such people as Yuri Orlov and other members of the Helsinki Watch Groups can be put behind bars.

Mr Deputy President, whilst not undermining the importance of this comment, one very important point should be emphasised: The West has no diplomatic representation in Kiev apart from the consulate of the United States of America which is prevented from functioning with any effect. Therefore, unlike its Moscow counterparts, the Ukrainian Helsinki Group receives little or no public pressure in its favour from foreign nations. In response to this, last year President Reagan announced that 9 November, the sixth anniversary of the foundation of the Ukrainian Helsinki Group, would be a day of tribute to it, commenting:

The long prison terms meted out to members of the Ukrainian Helsinki Monitoring Group for their courageous activities to secure greater freedom in the Ukraine are graphic testimony to the inability to communism to compete with the principles of freedom in the market-place of ideas. The flagrant persecution and imprisonment of Ukrainian citizens for their attempts to exercise basic human rights is an International embarrassment to the Soviet Union and proof that the Soviet Union has failed to live up to its pledges to honour the understandings embodied in the Helsinki Accords.

Mr Deputy President, we in this Senate chamber have always regarded ourselves as having a particular function of protecting the rights of individuals, particularly those who do not have a say in other spheres. Members of the Ukrainian Public Group to Promote the Implementation of the Helsinki Accords have suffered because they are attempting to monitor the implementation of the agreement that was reached at Helsinki. The evidence is clear that that agreement is regarded by the Soviet Union as a scrap of paper when it comes to the responsibilities that is is required to bear as a result of it. Instead, the Soviet Union incarcerates the very people who, by virtue of that agreement, have formed themselves into groups to see that the agreement is honoured. We in this Senate should therefore take this opportunity, not only on behalf of the Group as a whole but also in particular on behalf of those members of the Group who have relatives in Australia, to adopt the motion and convey to the Government of the USSR our deep concern at the repeated harassment of the Ukrainian Public Group to Promote the Implementation of the Helsinki Accords. I commend the motion to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —(New South Wales) (2.59)-I rise to firmly support Senator Harradine's motion which requests this Government to convey to the Govenment of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics its deep concern at the repeated harassment of the Ukrainian Public Group to Promote the Implementation of the Helsinki Accords. Senator Harradine has explained to the Senate the history of the Helsinki Accords, the expectation of all of the humanitarian civil population of the Western world that the Soviet Union will change or at least try to change its policy on human rights, a policy which really does not exist at all except in its constitution. But the constitution is a written book and is not necessarily to be adhered to. Senator Harradine has explained to us how the Ukrainian Group has been singled out as the most persecuted group. Members of the Group have been imprisoned. Some of them have committed suicide and some are still in psychiatric hospitals.

SPEECH.PARA: Last night we heard Senator Coleman reading to us a letter from a prisoner in the Philippines describing the life in prison there. I was deeply moved by it, as I am sure all honourable senators were. But that is one person and a person who was able to get the message to the world. The interesting fact was that the letter was allowed to be sent out to the groups of Amnesty International. But what I was amazed at were the conditions in that prison which the fellow described. He mentioned not once, but twice, that they have liturgical sessions. That means, I suppose, masses or observation of Sundays and all the rest; that they have a guitar; that they have had tape recorders and so on. But the conditions in that kind of prison and the prisons in which the Ukrainians and any one in the Soviet Union who is described by its laws as an anti-social parasite are imprisoned is quite different. Solzhenitsyn told us all about that. There are no guitars in Soviet prisons, there are no tape recorders so that prisoners can listen to music, there are no family reunions every Sunday to pray together. There is nothing like that at all and there are no letters which we can read from those people who are imprisoned in the Soviet Union because, first , they are not allowed to write them and, second, they are not allowed to be mailed outside. I do not intend to say that I am condoning the Philippines for the treatment of its political prisoners. I should like to say only that when we hear a description of a prison there and then compare it with descriptions of other prisons such as Solzhenitsyn has described in his Gulag books, then we realise what is happening under socialist and communist regimes, and not only there but also under other regimes.

As Senator Harradine mentioned, Ukrainians have been singled out in their persecution, and they were singled out for one purpose. They are one of the largest national groups in the Soviet Union. They have, strangely enough, representation at the United Nations, together with Byelorussia, but that does not mean that we have a Ukrainian ambassador in Canberra. The Helsinki Accords were the great hope of all humanitarians. It was hoped that the Soviet Union would relent in its oppression of anyone who even dared to criticise in a small way the system of the Soviet Union Government today. It is strange that all of those who believed in the Helsinki Accords have seen that nothing has changed in the Soviet Union in regard to human rights.

In relation to the Helsinki Accords Solzhenitsyn said that they represented the final solution of World War II, the absolute crystallisation of a divided Europe , the transformation of the Iron Curtain into a Steel Girder. He went on:

The fact is that the Helsinki agreement was viewed by the President of the United States as a new opportunity for humanitarianism, and by the Premier of the Soviet Union as a final termination of all Western interference in East European affairs.

These are the facts which are more real today than ever before. If we hear today that the Soviet Union does not have Stalin any more therefore it is much more human, let me remind honourable senators that it was not only Stalin who was the total dictator. There were others after him and others are still coming. The communist system will never change, regardless of who is in power. I conclude my remarks with a plea by way of another quote from Solzhenitsyn. He said:

The Communist leaders say, 'Don't interfere in our internal affairs. Let us strangle our citizens in peace and quiet'. But I tell you: Interfere more and more. Interfere as much as you can. We beg you to come and interfere.

We can see and we have seen from many examples how Western world media and pleas from concerned people were able to alleviate or even free some of the so-called dissidents in the Soviet Union. I therefore fully endorse and support Senator Harradine's motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government does not oppose the passage of this motion. Indeed, the substance of it is consistent both with our own attitudes as a democratic socialist party and our own actions in Government. The Soviet Government can be in no doubt regarding the intensity of feeling in Australia about continuing human rights violations in the Soviet Union. The Government deplores the very poor human rights record of the Soviet authorities. We are aware that Ukrainian dissidents in particular, the subject of this motion, have suffered very severely and they represent a disproportionately large group of those sentenced in the Soviet Union to terms of imprisonment for what would in the Western world be regarded as political crimes. We are also aware that the various groups which were formed to monitor the Soviet Union's obligations under the human rights provisions under the Helsinki Final Act which was signed in 1975 have been systematically subjected to harassment, arrest, and imprisonment. Faced with such unremitting pressure, the few remaining members of the Moscow-based Helsinki watch group announced in September 1982, as has been said in this debate, that the group was forced to disband. The Australian Embassy in Moscow has instructions to monitor closely developments in the human rights area and to keep the Government informed on a regular basis. It is an unfortunate fact that the provisions of the Soviet penal code, in particular those relating to so-called anti-Soviet agitation and propaganda, are formulated in such a way as to allow the conviction and sentencing of individuals such as those participating in the Helsinki watch groups. Official representations on behalf of such individuals or groups thus invariably are met with the argument, that Senator Lajovic mentioned, that their treatment is in accordance with Soviet law, that it is an internal affair of the Soviet Union and that Australia has no standing in the matter. Together with other Western nations, however, Australia will continue to urge the Soviet Union to abide by the human rights principles embodied in the United Nations Charter and the Helsinki Final Act. If information coming to our attention indicates that further action on our part may be warranted, we will give very careful consideration to what steps might be usefully taken in that respect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I briefly join in the debate to support Senator Harradine's motion and to commend him on his initiative in bringing it before the Parliament. I commend also the statement that has just been made by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). What has been said needs to be said very often. The important thing is that what is being done in the Soviet Union- in other countries as well, of course, but particularly in the Soviet Union-will not flourish if constantly exposed to the light of day and if people keep telling the Soviet Union that this conduct is not in accord with its undertakings, with its signature to the Helsinki Accords and earlier covenants with the United Nations. As members of the Amnesty International parliamentary group we are conscious of the particular brutality which the Soviet has shown to many prisoners, particularly in the areas of psychiatry. We realise that it is not just in the Ukrainian case that the Soviet Union adopts this attitude but also in many others.

SPEECH.PARA: I was in the Soviet Union visiting the Moscow group of Amnesty International which, of course, can no longer operate because nearly all its members are in prison. Fortunately, its president is not in prison. He was expelled from the country with his family. He has gone from being an unemployed man, a mathematician of considerable ability, to a man with a high position in New York where his talents are recognised. But he, like others, still suffered. When I was in the Soviet Union it was constantly put to me by the people who are trying to uphold the Helsinki rights and to bring them to the notice of those powers that the spotlight-that is a word they constantly used-must be turned on to the Soviet Union, that with campaigns something might be done. In 1976 I had the pleasure of bringing the latest report from Moscow and making it available to the Helsinki powers. I regret that very little was done with it by the 35 Helsinki powers. The same point was made by another group.

Recently there have been vigils throughout Australia on behalf of the Jewish people, the refusniks and others who want to leave the Soviet Union. Two or three years ago 50,000 were leaving; this year between 1,000 and 2,000 will be allowed to leave, although hundreds of thousands more are qualified to leave. The people left in the Soviet Union wanting to leave have said: 'Make a lot of noise. Keep making a lot of noise. That is something which will stir them'. We heard Senator Lajovic make reference to Solzhenitsyn and his remark: 'interfere and keep interfering'. It is always the same message of what must be done in this community.

I remind the Senate of the report-it may have already been mentioned in debate- of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence entitled 'Human Rights in the Soviet Union'. That Committee undertook a thorough investigation just a few years ago and presented its report, I think in 1980. One of its recommendations was:
It is recommended that the Australian Government make every use of appropriate opportunities to: (a) give full support for the principles contained in the Final Act of the Helsinki Agreement;
(b) join other democracies in protesting against the repression of Soviet citizens who are monitoring the extent of the USSR's compliance with the Helsinki Agreement; and
(c) seek the release from Soviet prisons and labour colonies of those Soviet citizens who have been imprisoned merely because of their Helsinki ''watch group '' activities.

This is doubly important to those people in the Ukrainian community who have suffered. There have been in some ways particularly vengeful activities against the Ukrainian people, who have suffered considerably in the last 60 years or so. One must remember that in the Soviet Union the Russian majority is superior. The other minorities are now becoming the majority people and there is a Russian dominance which they are determined to maintain. Bigger groups like the Ukrainians seem to stand in the road of that, so they have suffered more than their fair share, if one can use those words, of the repressions which have taken place over the last 60 years.

I trust that the Government will keep taking every opportunity to draw attention to the repressions which in this motion refer particularly to the Ukrainian people and to those who are valiant in the support of human rights- people like Anatoly Shcharansky who is in prison, who is ill, and on whose behalf people have made representations. There are many such people in this situation. I know that when they learn that motions such as this are brought forward and that other democracies are showing an interest in their plight it will greatly improve their morale. Such knowledge helps them to fight on in terrible circumstances. From this point of view, I think that a motion such as that which has been moved is one which deserves every support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly in this debate , which is an important one. I congratulate Senator Harradine in bringing it forward for the attention of the Senate. Obviously, it has unanimous support in this place. On behalf of the Opposition, I certainly add my voice to that support. The motion states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate requests the Australian Government to convey to the Government of the USSR its deep concern at the repeated harassment of the 'Ukrainian Public Group to Promote the Implementation of the Helsinki Accords'.

Senator Evans indicated that the Government is not opposed to that motion and that it accepts the need to press the Soviet Union from time to time in regard to the obvious breaches and violations of human rights in that country. They are well documented and well known and not a subject on which there needs to be any debate in this chamber. I would also like to support the remarks Senator Missen made in emphasising the need to keep repeating our disapproval. There may be a tendency for the members of the Department of Foreign Affairs to feel that if there are too many protests they will not be listened to, but I think it is important that Australia, as Senator Missen advocated, continually press these matters. When it is well documented that there are gross violations to human rights such as those which Senator Harradine has shown occur in regard to the particular group in the Ukraine, I believe Australian intervention is called for .

I understand that this group has been one of the most active and effective and is one of the best known, if not the best known, of the groups in the Soviet Union which have been set up to monitor the observance of the Helsinki agreement of 1975. That agreement was a landmark in this field, but it called for dramatic Soviet initiatives to ensure the observance of human rights in the Soviet Union. We know that the Soviet Union has not observed the responsibilities which it adopted when it entered into that pact. Since 1980 the same body on security and co-operation in Europe as that which met at Helsinki and entered into those Accords has been in continuous conference in Madrid. Even though it has met again and reaffirmed the principles, the Soviet Union, although it formally adheres to those principles, does not really observe them.

There has been quite a lot of material, particularly from Amnesty International , in relation to this matter. The types of harassment to which these people are being subjected have been documented. Senator Harradine has mentioned some of them. I do not propose to repeat them all, but obviously they include trials in secret, when people are just assigned their lawyer and even human rights of the most minimal kind are not observed.

In addition to that, there has been a constant policy of harassment of members of these groups even though they have not all been brought to trial and sentenced to long periods in detention. In many cases, of course, people are detained in psychiatric hospitals on the grounds that they suffer from schizophrenia because they do not agree with the policies of the Soviet Union or that they are anti-Soviet in some way in the eyes of the Soviet Union itself or the Soviet legal system. This is a matter of real concern. It is pleasing that the Government has agreed to support the motion. I hope it will give effect to it as soon as possible. I also believe we are indebted to Senator Harradine for having brought this matter to the attention of the Senate today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Australian Senate condemns the systematic deprivation by the Islamic Republic of Iran of the most basic rights of citizens of that country whose only crime is that they are members of the Baha'i and other minority religious faiths .

It is fortuitous that these motions, notice of which was given on the same day, have come up for debate in the Senate today. I am grateful that the Senate has seen fit to support the motion moved by Senator Harradine on a related matter concerning human rights in another part of the world. I hope the Senate will see fit to support my motion.

I belong to one of the religious faiths which are having difficulties in Iran. My motion has been moved at the behest of members of the Baha'i community in Australia who are frantic, concerned and unhappy about what is happening to their brothers and sisters in Iran in what is emerging as a systematic regime of persecution and genocide. I suppose it is fair to say that the theocratic state has many drawbacks, but absolute theocracies are potentially evil and potentially dangerous. We see in Iran an absolutist regime which is unwilling to acknowledge the rights of other people to a view about their lives, their beliefs, or how they should live them.

This matter has been raised previously in the Parliament. I am reminded that my former colleague and friend, former Senator Puplick, raised the matter in the Senate in March 1981. It was raised in another place by the honourable member for Mackellar (Mr Carlton). On both those occasions the Parliament saw fit to support and agree with the propositions that were put. In March 1981 a serious situation existed in Iran in relation to members of the Baha'i faith and other minority groups. The situation is more serious now; their need is more extreme. When this matter was raised in the Senate in March 1981 honourable senators saw fit to deplore the continued persecution of religious minorities and, in particular, members of the Baha'i faith. I am asking the Senate today to vote for a motion to condemn what is going on in Iran, to condemn the systematic deprivation-it is not occasional, it is systematic, planned, determined and ongoing deprivation-of the rights of the Baha'i people.

Since that time many groups have raised their voices. However, it is necessary to raise our voices again here today. Despite world protests, despite the efforts by Amnesty International, despite motions submitted to the Human Rights Commission, the Ayatollah Khomeini and his Iranian Government have continued their campaign against those religious minorities whose crime is that their beliefs diverge from those of the Government. Since the Ayatollah came to power in Iran Baha'is have had their property confiscated, have faced summary execution and have been subjected to laws which effectively bar them from any kind of work. A report in the Sydney Morning Herald on 4 July this year, quoting the Guardian newspaper in Britain, stated:
It is now feared that Ayatollah Khomeini's Islamic regime has begun a macabre drive against women's liberation-because the religion of those executed preaches sexual equality.
That paper was reporting the hanging of two women earlier in June. Their crime was that they had asserted and stood up for the rights of women.

The Baha'i religion is a gentle religion. The basic principles of the Baha'i faith is that its followers believe in the oneness of mankind. They believe in the independent investigation of truth, the common foundation of all religions, the essential harmony of science and religion, the elimination of prejudice, universal compulsory education, spiritual solutions to political, economic and social problems. They believe in a universal auxiliary language and the seeking of world solutions to some of the problems facing us today. These are not evil beliefs. There is nothing in their practices which is evil or which requires them to be attacked. They seek to make life easier. They respect other religions . Some honourable senators may have attended Baha'i services. The Baha'is have a splendid place of worship at Ingleside near the northern beaches of Sydney. It has been my pleasure to go there and join the Baha'i people. They are gentle, they are accepting, they are tolerant and they are community builders. If they are like that in Australia, I am willing to believe they are like that throughout the world.

The Baha'i religion dates back 130 years. Since that time it has expanded rapidly throughout the world. It is present in most countries. It is the largest religious minority in Iran. It is interesting that the constitution of Iran which protects religious minorities-it protects the Jewish religion, Christianity and the religion of the Zoroastrians-does not protect, mention or recognise the Baha'i faith. The members of the Baha'i faith were originally members of the Islamic faith. They are regarded by the regime in Iran as being heretics. Because of this the Islamic revolutionary regimes in countries such as Iran regard them as heretics and deviants to the true religion and have persecuted them in a systematic way.

Religious prejudice against the Baha'i community has become institutionalised in Iran. The situation was not good before the revolution. Let us not look at this through rose coloured glasses. Under the Pahlavi regime the Baha'is suffered discrimination because they were still regarded as heretics in an Islamic country. But they had a place and they could cope. The situation has become intolerable since the revolution. The Baha'i faith has never been granted recognition as an independent religion by the Iranian Government under the Iranian constitution. There is a lack of basic constitutional safeguards for the Baha'is. This has meant that successive governments have enacted discriminatory legislation which has severely curtailed any basic rights which they have had and any freedoms we would regard as the automatic right of any citizen in our community. After the Islamic revolution there occurred, and has continued to occur, a systematic and co-ordinated campaign of persecution against the Baha'is . The aim of the campaign, which still continues, is nothing less than the total removal of the Baha'i people and the Baha'i faith from the country. To achieve this, no measure it too great. The campaign involves murder, hangings, trials and expropriation-matters which I will set out in little while.

As recently as 5 August this year we heard reports of a further 24 Baha'is being arrested. Most of those who are arrested end up being executed. Currently, 500 local institutions which administer Baha'i affairs-they are called local spiritual assemblies-exist in the cities, towns and villages of Iran but exist only tenuously. It is the members and appointed officers of the National Spiritual Assembly and of the local spiritual assemblies who are said to constitute the leadership of the Iranian Baha'i community. It is these people who are the targets of the campaign which is going on.

In preparing this motion I asked myself: What is the reason for this persecution? I have already indicated that the religion itself is regarded as heresy and the members of its faith are regarded as heretics to Islam. Charges have been made that the Baha'is co-operated actively with the Shah's regime. Charges have been made that they are opposed to the present regime. These charges could have been cooked up, or levelled equally, against the vast majority of Iranians, including many members of the clergy. This applies especially when the charges are brought systematically against Baha'is because they are Baha'is, not because of what they may have written, said or done. One can see that this is in fact a convenience. I remind honourable senators that the Baha'i religion is one which preaches non-involvement in politics. They are, however--

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps they are sensible.

—I think they would be welcome in this country with its spirit of ecumenical concern. They are loyal to the government of the day. I am sure that that is something that Senator Ryan would also find very acceptable. There is no evidence and there has never been that they are attempting to overthrow the Khomeini regime. However, what matters today in Iran is not so much whether the Baha'is as a group actually co-operated with the former regime but that many Iranians, particularly members of the Khomeini administration, believe that they did and they have been given no chance to prove that the charge is false. They are not getting the right to a fair and proper trial. Arrests which take place follow no proper procedures. No proper procedures are followed in the confiscation of the property. Moreover, the arbitrary execution of Baha'i people-families, citizens and communities-takes place.

SPEECH.PARA: The forms of persecution to which they are subject include the confiscation and destruction of community assets. This has taken several forms. There has been destruction of their holy places and their religious sites. This has included the destruction of their most holy shrine in Iran, where the Baha'i faith had its beginnings in 1844. There has been destruction and desecration of their cemeteries. The Baha'i hospital in Tehran, which served all races and religions, was confiscated and all rights to it were denied the Baha'is. The national Baha' i centre in Tehran was seized by fanatics and was designated as a free Moslem university.

In addition to confiscation and destruction there has been fiscal strangulation . Baha'is have been deprived systematically of their means of livelihood, of the right to seek jobs, of their homes and of their possessions. They have been persecuted by physical means. There has been physical intimidation to compel recantation of their faith. They have been persecuted by dismissal from public and private employment on the ground that they belong to what has been described as a depraved religion. Pressure has been exerted on private employers to dismiss the Baha'is. Faced with the regime in Iran, it is not surprising that some private employers have acquiesced on the ground that these people are heretics. There has been persecution in that they have been denied burial facilities. They have been forced to bury their dead in barren stretches of land . They have not been given the same rights after death as are accorded other citizens of their country. They have been denied education and vocational training. They are not allowed to enrol in many schools or universities without declaring their religion. If they declare that they are of the Baha'i faith they are not permitted to receive an education in Iran.

This is indeed a sorry list of persecutions. I must also point out, however, that at regular intervals I have received from the Baha'i community in Australia letters setting out the latest sad events. In May of this year I received a letter from Mr Bolton, a Baha'i friend in Sydney, advising me that he had recently received reliable information on the further execution by hanging of three innocent Baha'i friends-two men and a woman-in Shiraz on 12 March 1983. He mentioned their names in his letter. Their bodies were buried by prison guards without the knowledge of presence of relatives and their families were not advised of the executions. The same correspondent advised me in June that a further 20 people had been executed in Shiraz in shameful circumstances, ten of them women from the age of 18 upwards. Their crime was that they were Baha'is and they had refused to recant their faith.

I received in June of this year from the National Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is of Australia Incorporated a letter setting out the names, first, of six Baha'i men who were hanged in Shiraz on 6 June; and, secondly, of 10 Baha'i women who were executed in Shiraz also on 18 June. Their names are in my possession. It is not really necessary for the purpose of this debate for me to incorporate those names in Hansard or read them out. In July I received a further letter from the National Spiritual Assembly of the Baha'is setting out yet another list of names of people executed for no good reason apart from the fact that they were adherents of a particular religion. Finally, in August this year, just a few days ago, I received yet another letter and yet another list. On this occasion the letter concerned 24 more Baha'is, including 10 women who had been arrested between 3 August and 5 August. The letter sets out in different places the names of each of those persons.

We have here a series of events which, had they occurred in Europe in the 1930s , would have been recognised as genocide, which is defined as activities directed to the elimination of a group from a society because of its beliefs. I believe that few honourable senators would not wish to support a motion expressing our revulsion and condemnation of what is going on. These are not random events; they are not the actions of some local authorities acting in a maverick fashion; they are the planned and approved actions of a theocracy determined to deny to some of its citizens the right to believe and practise their beliefs. I hope that the Senate will see fit to support and approve this motion. If it is approved by the Senate I hope that we can ask Mr President to pass on the contents of the resolution to the appropriate Iranian authorities so that they may be aware of the views of this Senate. I seek from honourable senators support for my motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Subject to a note of caution which I shall sound before I sit down, the Government does not oppose this motion. Indeed, we could not do so because for a considerable time the Government, along with just about everyone else around the world, has been deeply concerned at the disturbing human rights situation in Iran, and in particular the actions taken by the Iranian authorities against the Baha'i community as outlined by Senator Baume today.

SPEECH.PARA: We have normal diplomatic relations with Iran and wish to see Iran play a full role in the international community. In our contacts with the Iranians, both in Tehran and in Canberra, we have expressed our concerns at the human rights situation in that country. Our embassy in Tehran has made direct representations to the Iranian Foreign Ministry and has also participated in a number of joint demarche to the Iranian Government with like-minded countries represented in Tehran. The latest of these approaches was made in July this year.
