Australia has spoken out strongly in the United Nations General Assembly and in the United Nations Commission on Human Rights against discrimination and persecution on religious or other grounds. We have taken up the specific issue of the Baha'is in Iran in these forums. At the 1983 session of the Commission on Human Rights the Australian delegation played an active role as a co-sponsor of the resolution condemning human rights violations in Iran, with particular reference to the Baha'is. We look forward to seeing the visit of the UN mission to Iran provided for in this resolution proceed as soon as possible. At this point I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the two-page copy of the resolution in question.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Question of the violation of human rights and fundamental freedoms in any part of the world, with particular reference to colonial and other dependent countries and territories 1/ 2/
The situation of human rights in the Islamic Republic of Iran
The Commission on Human Rights.
Guided by the principles embodied in the Charter of the United Nations, the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and the International Covenants on Human Rights.

Reaffirming that all Member States have an obligation to promote and protect human rights and fundamental freedoms and to fulfil the obligations they have undertaken under the various international instruments in this field.
Recalling General Assembly resolution 36/22 of 1981 and General Assembly resolution 37/182 of 17 December 1982 on the practice of arbitrary or summary executions,
Recalling also General Assembly resolution 36/55 proclaiming the Declaration on the Elimination of All Forms of Intolerance and of Discrimination Based on Religion or Belief,

Recalling further its own resolution 1982/27 of 11 March 1982 in which the Commission inter alia urged the Government of the Islamic Republic of Iran to respect and ensure the rights of all individuals within its territory and subject to its jurisdiction,
Mindful of resolution 1982/25 of the Sub-Commission on Prevention of Discrimination and Protection of Minorities,
Taking note of the Edict of the Government of the Islamic Republic of Iran of 16 December 1982 calling for the correction of judicial abuses,
Having carefully examined the report of the Secretary-General (E/CN.4/1983/19) and the relevant sections in the report on summary or arbitrary executions (E/CN .4/1983/16),

Encouraged by the report of the Secretary-General (E/CN.4/1983/52) in which he announces a mission of his Representative to the Islamic Republic of Iran, providing an opportunity to clarify further the situation of human rights in that country,

1. Expresses its profound concern at the continuing grave violations of human rights and fundamental freedoms in the Islamic Republic of Iran as reflected in the report of the Secretary-General, and particularly at the evidence of summary and arbitrary executions, torture, detention without trial, religious intolerance and persecution, in particular of the Baha'is, and the lack of an independent judiciary and other recognised safeguards for a fair trial;

2. Urges once more the Government of the Islamic Republic of Iran, as a State party to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, to respect and ensure to all individuals within its territory and subject to its jurisdiction the rights recognised in that Covenant;

3. Requests the Secretary-General or his representative to continue direct contacts with the Government of the Islamic Republic of Iran on the grave human rights situation prevailing in that country, excluding the situation of the Baha 'is;

4. Requests also the Secretary-General or his representative to submit to the Commission on Human Rights at its fortieth session a comprehensive report on the direct contacts and the human rights situation in the Islamic Republic of Iran including conclusions and suggestions as regards the respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms in that country;
5. Requests once more the Government of the Islamic Republic of Iran to extend its co-operation to the Secretary-General or his representative;
6. Decides to continue its consideration of the human rights situation in the Islamic Republic of Iran at its fortieth session.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to the most recent reports of executions of Baha'is in Shiraz, our missions to the United Nations in New York and Geneva pursued inquiries with the United Nations secretariat to ascertain whether an approach to the Iranians through the United Nations would be of value. We were advised that the secretariat was currently following up the resolutions adopted by the Commission on Human Rights, including the question of the visiting UN mission.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is aware that many members and senators in the Australian Parliament are concerned at the plight of the Baha'is. That has been evident from debate on previous occasions, and is evident again from Senator Baume's contribution today. I believe this concern is already well known to the Iranian Government. It is important that any further actions on Australia's part-this is the note of caution that I foreshadowed-should, however, be as effective as possible and, indeed, should not risk being counter-productive. In this respect, the negative reaction, if I might put it euphemistically, of the Iranian authorities to President Reagan's public intervention on behalf of the Baha'is recently, in Shiraz, should perhaps be borne in mind. The Government will therefore continue to monitor the human rights situation in Iran and express its concern over the Baha'is and other human rights issues in ways that will be as constructive as possible and, in particular, which will not put the Baha'i community at even greater risk than it is at the moment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish briefly to join with the strong support given to the motion so ably moved by Senator Baume. I believe that this action is necessary. As I said on a previous occasion, it is necessary for us to remind the world constantly of this persecution of the Baha'i community. As in the case of Senator Baume from New South Wales, there is a substantial number of people of that faith in Victoria, the State which I represent. Many have approached me and I know they are terribly concerned about the inability of countries outside Iran to achieve very much so far in regard to this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: It is terrible when we have such systematic destruction of a group. They are the words Senator Baume has used in his motion, and that is what it is-a systematic destruction of human rights. It is not just a matter of some temporary prejudice sweeping across a community; it is not just a case of some breakdown in views. It is quite clearly a determined attitude; a determination to build up hatred towards the people who belong to that community. As Senator Baume said, this has led to the death of a great number of the leading Baha'is in Iran and therefore a weakening of that community and its very organisation. This in turn has led to an inability to maintain its religious and cultural needs. Senator Baume also described the deprivations suffered by this group in an educational sense. That is terribly important because it means probably the permanent destruction of a community inside Iran. One of the criticisms made by the Iranian Government is that the Baha'is chief shrine happens to be in Israel. Baha'is have been in that part of the world for quite a while. That is used as a specious excuse to suggest that, therefore, they are obeying the dictates of the Israeli Government. It is that type of prejudice and appeal to false nationalism which is so regrettable.

This Parliament carried resolutions some two years ago expressing its concern about the situation. In 1981 I happened to be in London at the time a massive protest was organised. It was held in one of the biggest committee rooms in the House of Commons and something like 1,000 people attended. Many of them were Baha'is but there were also many other people who believe in liberty. I was asked, as a visiting member of this Parliament, to join the panel and speak with a number of very significant British politicians and community leaders. The fact that the Australian Parliament had adopted resolutions on this matter-I think it was about the first to do so-was warmly received by the people there. After the meeting I received many thanks from a great number of Baha'is who were concerned about what they could do. They saw Australia, a country very distant from Iran, as one country that was taking a positive step. Therefore, it is important that we keep taking these steps.

I recognise the note of caution raised by the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans). Of course, we must not take action which may lead unnecessarily to further distress and attack on the Baha'is in Iran but one cannot just ignore these things and allow a community to disappear and go out of existence. Sometimes so great is the state of terror in a country that it is very difficult to do much. The Amnesty International organisation can adopt prisoners of conscience and where there are at least trials-even in the Soviet Union there are trials-someone can be there to observe them; something can be done. But unfortunately, in cases like Idi Amin in Uganda and now the regime in Iran, things become bestial and there is no reasoning. Deaths happen without trials and it is very difficult for the normal steps to be taken, with much effect, by international organisations. Therefore, I think parliaments must indicate to countries like Iran the horror that we feel at the behaviour that has taken place. Therefore, I warmly welcome and support this motion, I hope that it will be carried unanimously by this chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —As someone who has formerly had a very close association with the Baha'is and their teachings, may I warmly support and adopt everything said by Senator Peter Baume in moving this motion. It relates to one of the most heinous examples of religious persecution and genocide. It is not only reminiscent of the very worst examples of history but also is something which one would hope that this world might be finding its way past. All too regrettably we find worse and worse examples of its continuation. The Baha'i religion is a religion of such excellence that my major question is as to its practicality in our imperfect world. It represents a gentle and non- interventionist belief in the most humane and fundamental principles. It is incredible that the regime in Iran is in a position in which it can attempt to justify upon any possible basis any measures of repression in relation to the Baha'is, let alone the revolting measures which are taken.

SPEECH.PARA: I join with others in wishing to express our revulsion and condemnation of the regime which is behaving in the way which has been described. I warmly support the motion and, duly acknowledging the warning expressed by the Attorney-General , Senator Gareth Evans, in speaking to this motion, nevertheless will support the request of Senator Peter Baume that when the motion is carried, as I hope it will be, it will be forwarded to the appropriate authorities, including the United Nations.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate is of the opinion that tertiary students in Australia have been disadvantaged by the precipitate action of the Labor Government discontinuing student loans before any of the promised alternative forms of student support have been put in place.

I gave notice of this motion on 21 April 1983. At that stage I imagined that the Government would be moving to honour one of its specific election promises-that is, to put in place some alternative to loans. Nothing has happened. What was a valid concern, objection and criticism in April is now a question of disgraceful concern to students across Australia. The context in which this matter is brought up has to be seen in relation to this week's Budget and in what this week's Budget failed to do for students across Australia. This was a Budget in which the financial support for Australia's tertiary students was cut in real terms. Their allowances, with the exception of the secondary allowances scheme-I acknowledge to the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, Senator Ryan, that that has gone up in real terms-have gone down in real terms. In real terms students in universities are worse off under this Budget. Students in universities are worse off under this Budget in real terms-that is, in what they can purchase-than they were last year. In the Budget last year I obtained significant real increases for Australia's students. I presented them. Where are they this year? In real terms, they are down. Students will be worse off in terms of cash or what the benefits are worth. They will not have available to them any kind of loans scheme.

I use this opportunity to correct an error in something which Senator Ryan said this morning. The increase in the means test has not been enough to keep up with wage increases. What that means is that fewer families-not many-will be able to qualify for entry into student support than could do so last year. The best figures that I could obtain show that from June to June wages rose by 6.8 per cent. This year the means test extension for students was 6 per cent. The means test has gone up 6 per cent. Wages have gone up by more than 6 per cent. Fewer families will qualify to get into the Goverment's schemes. When they do get in the allowances are lower in real terms. It is in that context, the context of abandoning Australia's students, of failing to honour a number of specific election promises directed to students and to their support, that this motion comes up and is relevant. I remind the Minister that this year she has managed to widen the gap between the unemployment benefit, which has gone up considerably, and student support, which has dropped in real terms. This year she has increased the disincentives against people continuing in education. She has made it worth people's financial while to go on to the unemployment benefit rather than remaining in education or training. Any reading of the figures makes this apparent. The gap between the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance and the unemployment benefit has worsened. Against this context, the place of student loans becomes relevant and a proper matter of concern for the Senate.

I remind honourable senators also that last year we introduced, and this Parliament approved, arrangements for student loans. Student loans were to become part of an additional support for those in educational institutions across Australia. They were to be available to those who wished to use them. They were to be made available at a considerable interest rate reduction. There was a considerable interest rate subsidy by the Government. There was to be a considerable holiday before the money had to be repaid. The repayments were to be limited by the earning and repayment capacity of the recipient of the loan. The Australian Labor Party, in going into the election, made a number of commitments. One of those commitments was to abandon the tertiary student loans scheme. Another of those commitments was to replace it with something better. Now we find that the Labor Government has abandoned the loans scheme and replaced it with nothing. Students are worse off not only because their allowances are worth less but also because a loans scheme which was previously available as an extra on which they could draw is no longer available and nothing has been brought forward to put in its place.

Some documents which deal with student financing have been produced. Many honourable senators will have seen the Beswick report which is entitled 'Studies of Tertiary Student Finances' which was tabled in the Senate on 18 May this year . Honourable senators will be aware that in the document various proposals for funds available to students were discussed and evaluated. The Beswick report came down favourably on the introduction of a portfolio approach to student financing-not to depend solely on one kind of support, not to depend solely on another kind of support-where students could depend upon a mixture of forms of support which might well include student loans. The Beswick report made no bones about it. It indicated that student loans are not bad; however, student loans should be supported only as part of an approach to students. That is, of course, what I was seeking. When, as Minister for Education, I came in with a loans proposal, I also came in with a real increase in the TEAS benefit. I recall that last year the TEAS benefit went up 20 per cent. This year it will go up 5 per cent. Last year, in real terms, it went up 9 per cent. This year, in real terms, it is down 6 per cent.

A loans scheme was appropriate as an adjunct. If I turn to page 32 of volume 4 of the Beswick report I can see that it discusses the place of loans in a comprehensive policy, because only a comprehensive policy of support is appropriate. If the Australian Labor Party were implementing what it promised we would be getting towards a comprehensive support. But it is one thing to promise and it is another thing to deliver. The Beswick report makes it clear that loans are neither good nor bad, but the context in which they are offered makes them appropriate or less appropriate. In paragraph 2.52 the report suggested that under certain circumstances student loans could serve a useful purpose.
The paragraph states:
. . . loans could serve a useful purpose . . .
(a) to meet short-time emergencies, especially when coupled with personal advice and in a co-operative institutional environment; or
(b) near the end of a professional course when prospects of a good income in the near future are well established; or-
I quote the third purpose:
(c) among certain social groups, or for individuals with particular preferences in living conditions, as an optional extra to top up other income including TEAS allowances.

The Beswick report in no way has discarded loans as a reasonable option. It has sought a portfolio approach to student financing, which might include family support, self-help, the provision of support through the tertiary education assistance scheme, the provision of loans and the provision of scholarships. Let us be quite clear. We have, from an authoritative body appointed by the Federal Government to study this matter and to report to it and to the Australian people , a suggested approach which should include student loans as one option. The Australian Vice-Chancellors' Committee, as recently as last April or May, in its writings put out statements supportive of the ideas of loans as an appropriate form of support for students in appropriate circumstances.

The Australian Labor Party promised to abolish the loans scheme which we had proposed. As the Government of the day it is entitled to do that and indeed it has done it. But it should not be forgotten that early this year, during the election which was held at the same time as the enrolment period, when no action was being taken to promote loans within universities, 700 to 800 students actually made applications for loans under the scheme. Did we have fun getting this information out in the Estimates Committee! We eventually got it. It was finally given to us during the hearing of Estimates Committee D by Mr Rolfe, one of the officers. In spite of the difficulties, between 700 and 800 students took it upon themselves to indicate that they wanted access to those loans. During the campaign to get legislation through to establish loans, some of those student politicians campaigning vigorously against the Bill left us in no doubt that if it were passed they intended to apply for loans themselves.

Be that as it may, the Australian Labor Party promised to abolish that scheme and to put in its place an alternative, an emergency loan scheme to be administered on campus. That was one of the litany of specific promises concerning education which this Government made and which it has already dishonoured. In addition it promised that the tertiary education assistance scheme would be reviewed and increased-another of the specific promises made and dishonoured. It promised that the gap between TEAS and the dole would be narrowed-another promise made and dishonoured.

The student loans scheme may have been ideologically unacceptable, but I put it to the Senate that the procedure which the Government should have adopted if it was not to disadvantage students was to put its new proposal in place and then discard the loans scheme it did not like. However, it has discarded the existing benefit and not replaced it. Our concern is that students on campuses in Australia have lost something which was available to them and have had nothing put in its place. It is for that reason that I moved: 'That the Senate is of the opinion that the students have been disadvantaged'. It is quite clear that they have been disadvantaged. They have lost a benefit. The fact that they have been disadvantaged even further in this week's Budget merely drives home the extent of this disadvantage and the failure of this Minister to be able to deliver upon the promises made so freely during the campaign by her predecessor the former shadow Minister for education matters, on behalf of her party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I oppose on a number of grounds the motion moved by Senator Peter Baume. First I must comment on his use of the word 'precipitate'. He admits that it was an undertaking of the Australian Labor Party in opposition to abolish the student loans scheme, and we made that undertaking for very good reasons, which I will explain to the Senator. As that undertaking was made last year and as some months elapsed before it was implemented I believe that the use of the word 'precipitate' is highly inappropriate. No one can say that he or she did not know that the Government intended not to proceed with that scheme. From the very outset of discussion about the student loans scheme we opposed it and said that we would not have such a scheme when in government. So to claim that there was somehow some precipitate action involved in this is as ludicrous and as false as most of the other claims that Senator Peter Baume made during his address.

SPEECH.PARA: I also remind the Senate of what we are talking about in terms of fulfilling election promises with regard to expenditure in education. Senator Baume told the Senate that in the last Budget of the Fraser Government he secured a significant increase for tertiary allowances. That is certainly true, and at the time it was acknowledged by us as being a constructive move. However, what he failed to remind the Senate of was that for most of the years that the Fraser Government was in office there was no increase, real or otherwise, for tertiary allowances-not one cent. That created a huge gap in the level of allowances which were available and the level we would like to see for students to be able to live in a reasonable way. The inadequacy of the present level of TEAS-we admit it is not all we wish it to be-is the responsibility of years of neglect by the Fraser Government. Coming in at the last moment with an increase as Senator Baume did last year, did not make up for those years in which the student allowances had been eroded.

During the many years in which the Fraser Government was in power the eligibility for student allowances was not increased either. However, in our Budget not only have we increased the level of allowances available to students but also we have liberalised the means tests applied to students. Instead of the 700 students that Senator Baume claims wanted a loan under the Fraser Government 's loans scheme, several thousand more will become eligible for TEAS. We regard that as being an important measure in achieving our objective of more and wider participation in tertiary education in this country.

Senator Peter Baume implied that had the electors decided differently from the way they did in March this year there would have been massive expenditure on education. I remind the Senate that the person my colleague Senator Walsh likes to refer to as the former discredited Treasurer, Mr John Howard, said on an Australian Broadcasting Corporation interview a couple of evenings ago that had he been Treasurer this year instead of Paul Keating he would not have increased expenditure in any area of public spending except defence and social security. So we have from the mouth of the former discredited Treasurer this statement that there would have been no increase in education at all under a Liberal government, whereas under the Hawke Labor Government there has been an increase. Honourable senators will be aware that the increase in student allowances is not as great as we would wish to see it. We still have a commitment to increase and to overhaul student allowances and we still wish to pursue a progressive policy of increasing them. We are by no means complacent that the level of increase we have been able to achieve in this extraordinarily difficult economic climate that we have inherited from the Fraser Government is adequate. However, it is a sign of our good faith in this area.

I turn briefly to our opposition to the loans scheme. In the view of the Government loans are not an efficient or an equitable means of providing assistance to students. There is extensive overseas experience of student loans schemes which shows that they are not successful and that there is a very high default rate. We would have expected a similarly high default rate here had a student loans scheme been implemented and, of course, they do very little in terms of widening the access of groups to universities.

If we had proceeded with the loans scheme that Senator Baume is so enthusiastic about, such a scheme would have placed a very heavy burden on the very groups that are already under-represented in tertiary education, that is, women, particularly mature aged women with children to support, Aborigines and poor people generally. Those groups already have little access to tertiary education. If access to tertiary education were to be made dependent on the ability to take out a loan, the access of those disadvantaged groups would be even worse than it is now.

One of the major concerns of the Government with regard to tertiary education is that it is not available broadly enough throughout the community. This Government supports tertiary education. We believe in the value of tertiary education for society, for the economy and for the individual. It is of great concern to us that the people who currently have access to tertiary education come from a very narrow socio-economic group. In other words, most people who are able to enter tertiary education come from the relatively affluent sectors of society. I know that there are exceptions to this generalisation but it is a sound generalisation nonetheless and a matter of concern to us.

At this point I will refer briefly to a recent study which has been made of patterns of participation in Australian tertiary education. I refer to the Anderson and Vervoorn study entitled 'Access to Privilege-Patterns of Participation in Australian Post-Secondary Education' which will be published next month. The significant finding of that study is that the socio-economic mix of students enrolled in higher education has altered very little since the 1950s . Students from families whose backgrounds are professional or managerial have a representation in higher education which is significantly out of proportion to their numbers in the community at large.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the name of that report, Senator?

—The name of the report-I am pleased that Senator Baume is paying attention to it-is 'Access to Privilege-Patterns of Participation in Australian Post-Secondary Education'. The authors are Don Anderson and Vervoorn. It will be published next month and has already been reviewed in the Saturday papers. Its findings are such that it should attract the attention of all people who are interested in having an equitable education system. Access to tertiary education is inequitable; the study I have quoted is only one source of evidence for that. Anybody who has spent any time on campuses throughout Australia will know that that is the case. If we had proceeded with a loans scheme we would have simply reinforced that current inequitable pattern.

SPEECH.PARA: No matter how loans schemes are set up, the ability of students to undertake loan repayments depends on having affluent families supporting them. Anybody in the Senate who went to university in the days when the teachers bond loan scheme was available would know that. It was always a great burden on students to have to undertake a loan which they would then have to spend the first years of their working life paying back. There has been an argument in favour of a loans scheme to the effect that if a student is to study medicine or law, he or she will be assured subsequently of a very high income and will be in a position to pay back a loan. That may well be true in the case of medicine and law, although it is not true for those graduates of medical or law schools who are now-I am pleased to say that there is an increasing number of them-using their professional skills in very low paid areas such as working for legal services, Aboriginal legal services or Aboriginal health services. It is certainly not true of students who undertake other degrees that lead them to work in the voluntary sector for organisations such as the Brotherhood of St Laurence and so forth, or for people who want to go into some other area of social commitment that does not bring with it a very high wage or salary.

A loans scheme would distort the kinds of courses that students would feel free to undertake but most significantly, as far as the Labor Government is concerned , it would do nothing to broaden the range of people in our community who have access to the very considerable advantages of tertiary education. It is for those reasons that the loans scheme was abandoned by us as soon as we were elected, as indeed we undertook to do.

I know that colleagues of mine want to make contributions on this matter also. In conclusion, I simply say that we are taking very seriously the need to provide more support to people seeking to enter tertiary education. We have as our major objective an increased participation in tertiary education. I believe that the steps that we have been able to take in the current very difficult economic circumstances will mean that more people will be able to go to university and that the lives of those who are currently eligible for the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme allowance will be a little less miserable than they have been in previous years. As I have said, that is not enough; it does not satisfy our aspirations for tertiary education and its availability in this country. But it is a significant first step and one which has come after years of erosion and neglect of support by the previous discedited Fraser Administration for students from poorer families. I oppose the motion moved by Senator Baume.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I support the motion of my colleague Senator Baume, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate is of the opinion that tertiary students in Australia have been disadvantaged by the precipitate action of the Labor Government discontinuing student loans before any of the promised alternative forms of student support have been put in place.

The operative words in the motion are 'before any of the promised alternative forms of student support have been put in place'. As the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) has said, I acknowledge that the Australian Labor Party, when it supported in November last year the introduction of the Fraser Government student loans scheme, stated: 'But if we gain government we will abolish the loans scheme'. But, at the same time, the Labor spokesman said: 'We will abolish it because we will make better financial provisions for students'. That was a clear promise linked with the policy statement that the loans scheme, though supported in November 1982, would be abolished by the Labor Party. That is the rub, the offence that leads us on this side of the chamber to support Senator Baume in this motion.

The students of Australia need to shake off their chains and wake up. They need to understand that under the Liberal Government more financial resources were available for tertiary study in Australia than there are currently, or will be next year, under the ALP Government. They can test that by any kind of analysis. It is already acknowledged in the Senate that the decisions of the Budget with regard to student assistance schemes will make available less real financial support through the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and through the post- graduate award scheme than was the case in the last year of the Fraser Government. At the same time, $50m of the loans scheme is not in place and neither are the alternative financial resources that the Labor Party promised to students. I contest that students will readily acknowledge that fewer financial resources are available in real terms from this Government than were available in the last year of the Liberal Government.

I was the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts that conducted an inquiry in October and November last year into the provisions of the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill 1982. It was a bipartisan committee. Senator Giles, a Labor senator from Western Australia, who is in the chamber, was Deputy Chairman of the inquiry. There were three Labor senators and three Liberal senators. Senator Macklin, an Australian Democrat senator, also took a close interest in the inquiry and attended many of our hearings. A wide range of submissions and witnesses came to public hearings. They included representatives of students, educational institutions, banks and so on. What was the conclusion of that inquiry? What did the Senate Committee find about the $50m per year loans scheme proposal of the former Government? First of all, it addressed itself to the two main objections which a minority, I contest, of students were putting up as disadvantages of the proposed scheme. The first was that this loan scheme would erode, they said, the existing student assistance program. The Senate inquiry found totally to the contrary. The second objection raised was that only certain students would be eligible for the loans; that women students, students whose courses would lead to lower incomes than that of others on graduation, Aboriginal students, students who came perhaps from low income families and students who could be discriminated against on grounds of age or even academic record, might not be as eligible as would some other students. The Senate Committee found that eligibility was available to all students alike, save that one criterion could disallow a loan to a student. That criterion was a pre-existing bad credit rating. No other criteria were to be taken into account. In other words, if a student already was in debt or was irresponsible in servicing a debt the loan would not be added to his difficulties. But there would be no discrimination on grounds of age, sex, type of course, future earning capacity or whatever. Certainly there would be no need for a parent, a cousin, a neighbour or a friend to be a guarantor of the loan. In fact, the Government was the guarantor. I see that Senator Robertson readily acknowledges this lack of discrimination in the Bill. Senator Giles, Senator Hearn, Senator Robert Ray and I all agreed that--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy President. The remark which the worthy senator made may have been intended to be facetious but it will have gone into the record. I certainly acknowledge none of the comments that are being made by Senator Teague.
—That is not a point of order. Senator Robertson may make a personal explanation later if he claims to have been misrepresented.
—I say to Senator Robertson, through you, Mr Deputy President, that that was in fact the finding of the six senators at that time. Conclusion No. 2 stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Apart from the eligibility provisions set out in the Bill which are to be administered by the Commonwealth Department of Education, the Agreement between the Government and the banks will restrict the banks to take into account only one criterion on which an eligible student's application for a loan can be denied: that is, a prior unsatisfactory repayment record already established by the applicant. Other factors such as future earning capacity, course of study, age, sex, academic record and socio-economic background will not be taken into account when banks are considering applications for loans.

That was a unanimous finding. My comment to Senator Robertson was that he would readily acknowledge that that was a unanimous finding because it is in the report of the Senate Standing Committee that was tabled in this chamber. So the two objections, put up by a minority group of students, which led to some concern in the earlier debate on this matter in the Senate, were put to rest by the inquiry. Let me read the first conclusion, which related to its being totally supplementary to the other existing forms of student assistance. We agreed unanimously to this conclusion:

The student loans scheme provided for by the Student Assistance (Loans Guarantee and Subsidy) Bill 1982 will not replace or diminish the grants schemes of student assistance, whether the Commonwealth Postgraduate Awards Scheme, the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme, the Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme or the Aboriginal Study Grants Scheme. The only significant effect of the loans scheme on these four grants schemes will be to supplement the benefits currently available under them. Eligibility under the loans scheme will be considerably wider than under the grants schemes.

I can only repeat that the students of Australia should shake off their chains and wake up. They should realise that this year the tertiary education allowance scheme will provide $180m in financial resources to students. The student loan scheme, which was disbanded, provided an additional $50m or some 30 per cent on the existing level of assistance. There is to be, under this year's Budget, a measly 5 per cent rise in expenditure on the tertiary education allowance scheme . That 5 per cent increase represents less than half of the inflation rate. Students will no doubt welcome the couple of dollars a week increase in the tertiary education assistance scheme allowance but will that approximately $8m in extra resources substitute for the $50m that would otherwise have been provided?

The informal sense of the promise given by the Australian Labor Party was: ' Look, this is an additional resource for students. In November 1982 we will allow the $50m in loans to take place. When we get into office we will disband the scheme but, at the same time, we will make available to tertiary students additional financial resources-meaning at least a $50m increase in TEAS expenditure or on special schemes that would achieve our joint purpose of widening access to tertiary education'. I say plainly that the words of the motion are manifestly true-that an additional substantial resource, $50m, has been denied the students of Australia's universities, colleges and the TAFE sector without any of the promised ALP alternative student financial resources being provided to replace them.

I now turn to recommendation 8 of the Senate Committee's findings. Recommendation 8 was also a unanimous recommendation. It looked to a still further financial resource being available to students of Australia. It states:

The Committee recommends that the Government distribute additional grants to higher education institutions for the specific purpose of ensuring that emergency loan funds for students in need operate at all such institutions. The existing loan funds should be supplemented as necessary to ensure that there is an adequate level of resources available.

These campus-based emergency loans funds are, in principle, I believe as warmly welcomed by Government members as they are welcomed by Liberal Party members, Australian Democrats and Senator Harradine. I think that the general purposes of these emergency loan schemes and their superior qualities, even when compared with the $50m bank-based loan scheme, are understood in this chamber. A number of us have spoken about them at length. I will briefly summarise how I believe they might operate. There could be a per capita distribution of moneys from the Commonwealth to all tertiary education institutions. A tertiary institution, if it is small, might receive $70,000. If it is larger, it might receive $200,000. There would be a fair distribution of moneys. The money would be given to a student emergency loan fund on each campus, administered by a loan committee responsible to the institution's council. Students with emergency financial needs could then apply directly to that loan committee. The average loan might be $300, $400 or $500, with an upper limit of about $1,000. I believe that the loans should operate without interest accruing whilst the period of agreed repayment is elapsing and that only after default would interest accrue on such a loan. The normal time of repayment for these rather small loans would be the end of the next summer vacation or the end of the summer vacation after that.

One of the points of genius about these emergency loan schemes which are campus based is that students see them as coming from a pool that is fixed, one that is only periodically supplemented by any government or by bequests from individuals . Therefore, if the loans are not repaid to the campus based loan fund some other student will be denied the financial resource to meet an emergency. When a bank is providing the money, or the Commonwealth or State governments are providing the money, I am sorry to say that sometimes some students, like other adults in the community, feel it less imperative to pay the money back on time. Notoriously, when there were teacher education bonds and scholarships under which money had to be repaid, it was considered less imperative to pay money back. But where the money will go back into a fund which will help other students, not to pay it back is seen by students to be very immoral because the student is denying the resource to his mate, to someone who is in much the same situation as he was when he received his loan. Available evidence about these emergency loan schemes-they have operated well in universities or colleges- indicates that there is a very high repayment rate and it is possible to serve hundreds of students. The money turns over. Because there is no interest accruing on most of the loans there is a diminishing real value in the loan fund but nevertheless that can be supplemented from time to time to continue to meet this area of need.

This is the kind of emergency loan which I am convinced the students of Australia were expecting from the present Government, partially to replace the Liberal Government's $50m loan scheme. But where is it? What has happened to it? Is it in the pipeline? Is it even being investigated? There is no evidence that it is in place. I do not wish to berate the present Government too strongly. I appeal to the Government on behalf of the students of Australia and, indeed, on behalf of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts which made this strong recommendation, that it be urgently considered and that, even before the beginning of the next academic year in 1984, there be a disbursement of funds. So far the Budget for this year has seen about $8m made available. Why not $50m? Why not include moneys for an emergency loan scheme?

I do not think honourable senators need to be reminded that there are some students who fall into particularly invidious financial need. Some students fail and need to repeat their studies. If they fail and are repeating their studies to catch up to where they should have been, they are not eligible for the tertiary allowance. Do we not help them through that period? Some students go away for a year and earn some money and then come back and catch up, using their own resources. Some students work part time at a higher rate during that year of catch up and they have the additional burden of employment as well as their studies and the worry that if they fail twice they may not even be able to continue their tertiary studies. How much benefit it would be to them if they had access to even $1,000 which they could repay over the next 18 months or two years without interest accruing. Some students-and perhaps there are some honourable senators who do not have much sympathy for them-come from families whose incomes are beyond the limit of the means test, which precludes them from obtaining the tertiary education allowance. Therefore they do not have any kind of public support for their living needs and at the same time they do not receive any direct financial help from their parents. They are cut out of the living allowance because of their parents' income but in many instances these students do not receive help from their parents. Are we to penalise those students and deny them the opportunity of tertiary study? What they do at the moment is study hard and at the evenings and weekends they gain employment to pay for their studies. These students would be directly helped, particularly in the last year of their studies if they had an emergency loan of $1,000 with the proviso that they paid it back in full out of their earnings when they were employed.

There are even some students receiving the tertiary education allowance who have a short term emergency need. They may be tossed out of the flat that they are living in for some reason beyond their control and have to come up with a bond-sometimes $300 or $400-shared by two or three students. Sometimes they have to take on new accommodation. How does an impoverished student find $300 or $400 when he has only got enough for his weekly expenditure? Some students, like other members of the community, suffer theft. If their books are stolen they may immediately have to buy half a dozen books at a cost of $200 or $300. So students face emergencies and I believe that these would best be met by an emergency loan fund, campus based.

I am aware, as Senator Peter Baume said earlier this afternoon, that the Beswick report entitled 'Studies of Tertiary Student Finances' recommends in its thorough study of student finances that there be a spectrum of financial resources available to students, including loan schemes of the type we have debated here today. Senator Peter Baume also referred to the decision of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee that there is a place for student loan schemes to be available to students. I therefore genuinely ask the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) to get the Government to consider the disbursement of moneys for emergency campus based loan schemes even before the beginning of the next academic year.

I speak principally for colleges of advanced education and for technical and further education colleges. Student loan schemes have been developed in many of the universities and much of the money on which they were built was disbursed when Mr Kim Beazley was Minister for Education in 1973. That preceded the abolition of fees in the next year. That money has dwindled. Some of that money was given away in grants but the great majority of our tertiary institutions did not receive any of it. Some of them were not in existence then and they were not included in the disbursement. This request is made not just because the Senate Standing Committee recommends it. It is not made just because Beswick recommends it. It is not made just because the vice-chancellors, the chief executive officers of the universities, or the principals of the colleges, would welcome it. It is made because there is an expectation amongst students that the Government will come up with alternative financial resources that will go some way towards the expectations that were created when promises were made at the end of last year and early this year.

The Australian and New Zealand Student Services Association, which is the professional association of counsellors, medical persons and career advisers in tertiary education institutions, is currently systematically studying the need for emergency loan schemes. I am sure that its submission to the Government could easily be obtained and it would be up to date. I urge the Minister to consult with the Australian and New Zealand Student Services Association in progressing such a scheme. I make a genuine plea that this debate today not just be one in which we on the Liberal side of the Senate appeal for most senators to support this motion, but also that the Government lift the urgency with regard to genuinely achieving the goals that it has set out with regard to participation, equity, access and all the other bits which without these substantial schemes amount to rhetoric.

The student associations of our colleges and universities ought to analyse objectively and carefully the track record of the Fraser Government and that of this Government in the years 1983 and 1984. Under which government would more financial resources have been available to students? The answer is undoubtedly that with the $50m loan scheme there would have been more. Finally, I note that there has been no direct response on behalf of the Government point to point to the recommendations of the Senate Standing Committee in the inquiry to which I referred. Given Senator Button's answer this week that the Government has set its own discipline to respond within three months of a Senate committee report, I hope that there might be in the September sitting a direct response to the nine recommendations and conclusions that are set out in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one member of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts which met and heard the evidence in relation to this inquiry into student loan schemes I briefly summarise the evidence and give what I believe is a somewhat more adequate exposition of it than we have just had from the Chairman of that Committee. It is true that the conclusions of that Committee were unanimous. I do not believe that was an unreasonable response in that particular political climate. However, as a result of listening to the evidence I was left with very many serious reservations about the wisdom of the proposed scheme. Certainly, I came to the conclusion that it was inappropriate, at least within the Australian academic system, and it has proven to be inappropriate in many other parts of the world. There were three main grounds on which I based my assessment of its lack of appropriateness. They were equity, educational implications and efficiency.

SPEECH.PARA: It was quite evident that loans are most attractive to those in least need and who in many cases might take the opportunity to manipulate the scheme to their own advantage. There was even some indication that relatively affluent students might take advantage of a low interest loan, invest it in higher rates of interest and cream off the pickings. Those in most need would be the least likely to take out loans, especially those who cannot be certain that immediately on graduation they can anticipate top level incomes, comfortable incomes or even any sort of income in the sort of economic climate in which we find ourselves. The Treasury was able to estimate for us that the repayment of a $3,000 loan-that would be the amount perhaps that the young person would borrow in $1,000 lots over the three years-would ultimately total $6,720 over its 10 years of repayment. The repayment of a loan perhaps by a medical student of $6, 000 taken out in $1,000 lots over six years would ultimately total $15,480. They may not be stunning amounts for people in our comfortable income brackets, but they are certainly daunting amounts for young people just starting out on their academic careers. Mature students with families, single parents or those anticipating marriage, women especially, cannot undertake such commitments and would not see themselves as making a responsible decision if they did so.

According to the submission from the Sydney University Student Representative Council the effect on women students would be very damaging. Women would be less able to repay the debt as even after graduation women earn less than men and have a higher rate of unemployment. In 1980 a survey done at Monash University revealed that 48.5 per cent of women did not believe they could or would be able to make the necessary repayments. The scheme that was being advocated by the Liberal Government excluded part time students, overseas students and students attending technical and further education colleges. The Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology submission which we had before us described the experience of its loan scheme, one which would receive the approbation of Senator Teague and one which I also find quite attractive. But there has been a very low take up of loans over the last few years despite the fact that the students repay no interest in the years in which the loan is made, 5 per cent thereafter to completion of studies and 10 per cent after completion. The submission observed that as times become harder students, especially those from lower socio-economic groups, have greater concerns about entering into debt. Their concern is that without the certainty of a guaranteed income at the end of a course they would be ill-advised to borrow.

The educational implications of a loans scheme such as that being advocated can be quite severe. The United State experience has shown that because of the ties between repayments and assistance available to new students under such schemes large numbers of health professionals including 5,000 doctors have prevented adequate assistance to 5,000 prospective health and related students by not refurbishing the loans available by making repayments. Course selection, length of study and whether to pursue tertiary education at all were matters which could be very strongly influenced by accessibility or otherwise to these types of loans. We are also assured by representatives of the student organisations who, I believe, were putting forward a majority point of view on behalf of their constituencies, that there could well be a discouragement of mature age students and a tendency towards short, vocationally oriented courses. These would be the effects of a loans scheme which it was feared would soon be seen as an alternative to needs based grants with liberalised eligibilty. Post-graduate study could be precluded altogether by the need to keep up repayments of loans incurred during initial courses. Retraining might be completely out of the question for somebody who looked forward to 10 years of repayment after graduation, according to one submission that we heard.

The Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) referred to the high level of default which has been identified in countries where loan schemes have been operating for some years. They are quite stunning in some instances. In all respects they show a quite unsatisfactory state of affairs. The United States Students Association sent information to the effect that there was a 20 per cent default rate in that country. Currently, about one million students are being pursued for being delinquent in their repayments. In the United Kingdom, even under a conservative government, a project to introduce a loans scheme was allocated and dropped twice and that Government refused to explain why. In Ireland a plan was likewise abandoned after it had been estimated that it would take 13 to 14 years before receipts would match outgoings within such a scheme. In Canada there is a 16 per cent default rate. In 1981 one report put total default debts to the Government in Canada at $732m. Sweden, Norway and the Netherlands reported that after 20 years the governments had recouped only 25 per cent, 30 per cent and 11 per cent respectively of the loans expenditure. In Denmark the Government found itself obliged to repay $17m to private banks which had acted as its agents. In 1961 Japan had recouped only 14 per cent of student loan funds, rising to only 20 per cent 10 years later.

Is it any wonder that the Australian Bankers Association was much less than enthusiastic about the scheme advocated by the Liberal Government? At the time of the inquiry, which was November 1982, plans were sketchy, to say the least. Administrative costs were unknown. Indeed, there was reluctance within the Australian Bankers Association even to disclose individual charges, let alone actually to let the students or their organisations know what these charges were going to be. Lengthy discussions between student organisations and the bankers' representatives had not reassured any of the parties. Theoretically, bankers would provide loans without discrimination on the basis of first come first served until the funds were exhausted with concern only, they assured us, for the creditworthiness of the individuals concerned. It seemed highly probable, however, that the average bank manager-I believe there are something like 6,000 in Australia-might find it difficult to disregard the usual bankers bias towards well dressed, well spoken students embarking upon lucrative careers, to the detriment of those without such advantages.

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh!

—I do have bank managers amongst my acquaintances as I am sure Senator Walters does. Treasury itself questioned the wisdom of a scheme which could cater for only slightly more than 30 per cent of potential borrowers, anticipating a demand for these low interest loans which the student organisations strongly questioned.

SPEECH.PARA: There were, on our reckoning, something like 15,000 eligible students in Australia and certainly no more than 5,000 would have been able in each year to gain the maximum loan of $1,000. The Department of Education acknowledged the need for financial counselling seen as essential by the student organisations but offered no assistance to provide this counselling. The provision of funds for such a loan in a climate, as I would remind honourable senators, in which there was perennial anxiety about the cessation of the tertiary education assistance scheme and the introduction of tertiary fees, was certainly better than nothing. I assure the Senate that it was on that basis that the unanimous report was issued. But students and their parents have long memories. They know that the Fraser years were ones of increasing hardship and disincentive towards tertiary education. They know of the Labor Party's long term commitment to the expansion of opportunity.

We regret the necessity of not being able to make a bigger contribution toward student assistance this year but of having to move modestly. At the risk of being tedious, I remind the Senate again of the $9.5 billion deficit which was left for us to sort out some how or other. The extra $33m in student assistance funding in this Budget will assist 8,500 students, as against the maximum of 5, 000 students who would have been assisted under the loans scheme.

It is useful, I expect, to be reminded by Senator Teague that a comparison between the well-being of students in 1983 and 1984 might be of long term value to this Government. I think it might be more useful if we had a look back to 1978, 1979 and 1980, or even all the years before the advent of the present Labor Government and noted the mood of depression, dejection and dispiriting demoralisation that was endemic within all the tertiary institutions as they felt the Fraser crunch on their funding. I know that Senator Teague will be comforted and very pleased to hear that the Tertiary Education Commission has been requested to report to the Minister on the adequacy of the scheme introduced in 1973 by Kim Beazley, to which he referred, by which tertiary institutions were provided with funds for genuine emergency cases. As the honourable senator commented quite correctly, this arrangement tends to be highly efficient. Considerable concern is shown for the educational implications of such loans. There is a high rate of repayment and sensitive counselling is provided. I have no hesitation in agreeing with the honourable senator that this is the way we should go.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is ironical to find this motion standing in the name of a senator who was a Minister in the Government whose razor gang cuts in tertiary funding produced one of the most widely supported student protests of recent years. I was involved in this area so I can vouch for that. The Australian Union of Students then spearheaded a strong campaign in opposition to the previous Government's student loans scheme and this was very strongly supported by tertiary students, both present and future-of course, at that time students in secondary schools were also affected as potential tertiary students-all over Australia. There were very good reasons for this widely based opposition to the loan scheme, by staff in tertiary institutions as well as students. Probably the most cogent reason was that a loans scheme is inherently discriminatory against those who most need help, particularly in a situation of scarce employment opportunities. I can assure honourable senators that it is a myth that all graduates immediately find any sort of employment, let alone well paid employment.

SPEECH.PARA: It is unlikely that students without assets or the prospect of financial support in the case of future unemployment would want to take up a loan with no guarantee of being able to repay it. On the other hand, a student who entered lightly into such a loan may be forced to default, like it or not, after graduation. The majority of beneficiaries of such a student loans scheme are likely, then, to be those in least need of help-those, for example, whose parents could afford to assist them, if necessary, in repaying a loan. Thus, the loans scheme was likely to make the opportunity of higher education further weighted towards the more privileged sections of the community, as Senator Ryan has explained.

Senator Giles has detailed how student loans schemes overseas have suffered a high rate of default. Since the Government was to be the guarantor for loans, the need to pay students' debts would have led to cuts in other sections of the education budget. There was widespread fear, too, among students, parents and tertiary staff that the introduction of student loans was the thin end of the wedge, that the dismantling of the tertiary education assistance scheme would follow, partly for the reason I just mentioned of having to finance defaults but also because that would have accorded with the previous Government's philosophy that the user pays.

If Senator Peter Baume were justified in his belief that students have been disadvantaged by what he terms the discontinuance of student loans-and incidentally, I do not believe one can discontinue something which has not started and I trust that the honourable senator did not intend to imply that actual loans had been discontinued--

TALK.START.PARA: —But the scheme was started.

—That is not the wording of the motion. If that belief were justified we might have expected a wave of protest from students when the scheme was abandoned. That has not happened. I certainly have received no letters or phone calls of protest. Neither have any of the many tertiary and secondary students I know expressed any sorrow over the demise of the scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, I point out that many campuses have money available for the sorts of loans that Senator Teague was talking about. The Commonwealth Banking Corporation offers campus loans with interest deferred in full until graduation. Alternatives are available for those who are lucky enough to be able to take them up. The only way to provide access to tertiary education for all sections of society is through the tertiary education assistance scheme. These living allowances enable students to survive, although frugally, without a debt hanging over their heads.
