TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Education and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the report of the Committee of Review into the Impact of Radford College-Volume 1. I seek leave to make a ministerial statement in connection with this report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee of Review into the Impact of Radford College was set up on 19 April this year to inquire into the impact of the new Anglican school on other schools in the Australian Capital Territory. The decision of the previous Government to provide capital funds for the college had provoked considerable controversy in the community and I decided it would be best if the issues involved could be studied and discussed in a comprehensive manner.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee was representative of the education community in the Australian Capital Territory. Its chairperson was Dr Don Anderson, a professorial fellow at the Australian National University who has had an involvement in the development of Australian Capital Territory education for many years. Two other members of the Committee had interests in independent schools and two had had long involvement in State school education through parent organisations. Other members were a leading trade unionist who was a member of the Interim Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, appointed to the position by the previous Government in February 1978, the Secretary of the Commonwealth Schools Commission, and an Assistant Secretary of my Department.

The terms of reference asked the Committee to review plans for the development of Radford College and to assess its impact on existing Australian Capital Territory schools. The Committee was directed to have regard to the Government's commitment to equal educational opportunities for all Australian children and to the maintenance and development of comprehensive, high quality government school systems. In undertaking this task the Committee was asked to identify ways in which principles that had emerged in the course of this review should be given further consideration.

In addition, the Committee was asked to report on the following four specific questions: How the impact of the proposed school on existing Australian Capital Territory schools can be assessed and monitored, and how any disruptive effects can be avoided; the level of fees that will be charged at the school and how it can be ensured that the school is accessible to the general community; the compatibility of resource levels of the school and those available in government schools; and in the development and approval of its educational program and the certification of students, the means by which the school may function in accordance with existing Australian Capital Territory arrangements.

The Committee made 27 recommendations, all of which were unanimous. A number of the recommendations relate to the future planning of education in the Australian Capital Territory and the involvement of the community in that planning. I believe strongly in the importance of the greatest possible community involvement in education, including planning. I welcome the public discussion which the report has already promoted on these subjects. Some misconceptions have arisen as a result of the report, however. Concerning the issue of integration, which was raised in the Committee's report, I would like to make it clear that this Government has no intention of pursuing a policy of integrating non-government schools with government schools. The other recommendations will be examined by the Government, with the benefit of community input, before the Government responds to those recommendations.

Problems in making a sufficient number of copies of the main report available to the public have been experienced. I am advised that an adequate supply will once again be available early next week. The deadline for the submission of community comment on the report has already been extended to enable thorough public discussion. If further problems with the availability of the report occur , I will be happy to extend the deadline again. Some advance copies of Volume II , the appendixes to the report, are now being distributed to organisations and printed copies of that volume will be made available as soon as possible. I present the following paper:
Committee of Review into the Impact of Radford College-Ministerial Statement, 25 August 1983.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

The Opposition welcomes the statement not least because it gives enormous relief to a community worried about the question of the integration of non-government school with government schools. Some matters in relation to the statement of the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan) need to be discussed and comment upon them is necessary. I direct the Minister's attention to her own words which appeared in the Canberra Times this morning-I also want to draw attention to an editorial which appeared in that newspaper earlier this year-in which she is quite critical of the activities of some members in the community and the campaign they have waged. The fact is that members of the Canberra community who have spoken publicly to try to put to bed the question of the integration of government schools with non-governemnt schools have been successful in their campaign. It has been a highly successful exercise. I have no doubt that what the citizens of the Australian Capital Territory have done in raising this issue and in brining it to the attention of the people has played no small part in bringing about this response from the Government and especially in bringing it about today. I have no doubt that the Government has directed its Minister to make this statement to put this issue to rest. The report of the Committee of Review into the Impact of Radford College is very important. It has been a very sorry story. The school we are discussing, the proposed new Radford Grammar School, is to be established by a free association of citizens exercising their right of association to form a new school for the education of children. The establishment of the Radford Committee or the Anderson Committee, whatever honourable senators want to call it, which produced the report, was one measure to make the exercise of that right by those citizens more difficult. There is no doubt that the establishment of this Committee has made the establishment of Radford College more difficult to achieve. It has made it more difficult for all those associated with Radford College to see their dream come to fruition.

After all, before the election-indeed, during the time I was the Minister for Education-the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority completed and presented a report on the impact of a third grammar school in Canberra. That report was made available for public discussion. A report has already been prepared on the impact of the new grammar school. We had a report about what it would do to enrolments. We had a report about what it would do to the existing schools in the Belconnen region. We knew that information. If the Minister was seeking that information she had only to examine existing documents to find it out immediately. In case she does not remember, the advice which we received at that time was the establishment of Radford College as a third grammar school would bring forward by two years the date on which certain high schools with declining populations might reach one of the decision points at which the Schools Authority would have to decide either to consolidate their activities or make some other decisions about their future. That date would have been brought forward from 1995 to 1993. But we already know that.

It was in the light of that knowledge and in the light of the determination of the Anglican synod and Anglican parents-I think at that stage 2,000 parents had registered their interest-that we certainly approved, supported, endorsed and provided money for the construction of Radford College. Honourable senators may recall that at that stage the members of the Trades and Labour Council in the Australian Capital Territory decided to mount a picket line to prevent the school being built which the parents wanted for their children. In the week before the election the present Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) promised that Radford College would be built. Anyone hearing the statement that Radford College would be built might have been excused for understanding it to mean that Radford College could go ahead; that the Australian Labor Party did not intend to put any impediments in the way of the establishment or operation of this school, but that was not the case. I understand that a legal opinion was sought as to whether or not the money could be withheld. Then a decision was made and Press reports that the Government did not intend to seek that option, appeared.

This Committee was established to examine certain matters about Radford College and certain other matters which go more widely to non-government options in education in every State and Territory of Australia. It is desirable to look at this report, to look at the people who have written it, to look at the value positions it espouses and say to the Government, 'We are delighted to hear what you say about integration but that is only one part of what this report addresses'. People will be looking to a whole range of other answers concerning the Radford Committee report. It is all very well to say that it is not the Government's intention to proceed with integration. There was plenty of reason for people to be concerned. I remind the Senate once again that the Australian Labor Party in the Australian Capital Territory formulated in 1982 a policy which it released this year. That policy talked about an integrated public system of education. I will quote what the ALP produced and promulgated within the Australian Capital Territory-not federally but here in the Territory:

The present division of schooling into government and subsidised private schools is inefficient, maintains inequality, generates conflict and division and its perpetuation is not in the best interests of the children of Australia.
I repeat, 'its perpetuation is not in the best interests of the children of Australia'. The document goes on to say:
An ALP Government would establish procedures to enable private schools to integrate into a restructured public school system.
All schools within this integrated public system would be fully financed from public sources, would not charge fees, and would be fully accountable for the expenditures of money.
The document states, in conclusion:
Schools which choose to remain outside the integrated public system would not be entitled to any public funds or benefits.

In the light of the existence of that document and its association with the Australian Capital Territory division of the Labor Party and the later emergence of these committee recommendations, which go right down the same track, is there any wonder that citizens' groups and parents in the Territory were worried?

TALK.START.PARA: —Alarmed.

—Citizens in the Australian Capital Territory were alarmed and the public meetings which were held bear witness to the extent of their alarm and concern. But the alarm went wider, if I may say so through you, Mr Deputy President, to my colleague Senator Teague, because the proposals have national implications. They could be used to direct the conditions under which the Commonwealth would fund any non-government schools anywhere in Australia. Mr Deputy President, I was interested in the value position of the Labor Party. I thought honourable senators would be interested in knowing also of some of the contents of an address to the Victorian Fabian Conference in April this year by Dr Don Anderson, who was the Chairman of the Radford Committee. I will simply read, without much comment, some of the things he said, as reported in the Journal of Advanced Education of 20 July 1983. We will see whether anyone reading these comments would have concern about the report and what it might mean. Dr Anderson says:

SPEECH.PARA: If secondary education is to be reformed into a system which provides for voluntary, majority participation to Year 12 or its equivalent, the burden will have to be carried mainly by the public sector. The task is made more difficult by the existence of a private sector which skims the cream off the operation . . . A condition of public funding to private schools should be that the operation of the recipient school should in no way detract from the operation of public education in its region . . . Even in normal times private schools detract from the public education by skimming off some of the best teachers, some of the more able pupils and most of the powerful and articulate parents who, if they were in the public sector, would be influential in demanding reform. At the present time , when the public schools are under tremendous pressure their undermining by private schools is particularly serious.

Given the content of that Fabian address, I would say the appointment of Dr Anderson as Chairman of the Committee more or less predicated in advance what kind of report we would get. The contents of the report are entirely consistent with the sentiments expressed by Dr Anderson and with those expressed in the ALP policy paper formulated a couple of years ago. Of course people in the Australian Capital Territory were concerned; of course they were alarmed. They do not trust this Government's approach to non-government schools; they do not trust what it intends to do and they do not trust its intentions in regard to the Radford report. How was the report received? Let us look at some of the Press comments. I refer to what the Canberra Times had to say in July, after the report appeared.

However, the most worrying thing about this whole exercise has been the total disregard by this Government of public interest. Today, at 2 o'clock, we called the Australian Government Publishing Service to make inquiries about the availability of this report, on which the Minister wants public discussion. She has acknowledged something about the lack of copies. As of today, the Publishing Service has a slim volume-volume III, which is a summary giving the findings but none of the arguments. It has never sighted volumes I and II. People in the Australian Capital Territory have not been able to purchase volumes I and II of this report. The honourable senator is tabling a volume today. People in the Australian Capital Territory have not been able to buy a copy. Today the Government's Publishing Service did not have it. Volume II, which contains the tables which people might want to examine to test some of the propositions and look at some of the evidence and the special papers, is not available. It has not been available.

I put it to the Minister that it is impossible for her to put any kind of date on the receipt of submissions until she can first guarantee that all three volumes will be made available to the public. I have been unable to obtain volume II. I have no idea of its contents. I have been unable to test them. The honourable senator has not done the Parliament the courtesy of giving us access to the three volumes which make up this report. The Government has chosen to hold these volumes to itself. The existence of volume III is not enough for public discussion to occur.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are available. They will be made public as soon as they come off the printing press.

—The honourable senator says that they will be made available as soon as they come off the press. I put it to the honourable senator that she cannot even conceive of cutting down the time for response until she knows that volumes I and II have been out for sufficient time for people to be able to make a response. Those volumes are not available now. People are not able to respond. It would be quite unthinkable for the Government to proceed to any consideration of this matter until volume II, in particular, is out and available. That is not within sight. I am delighted to have noted in the last few days in the Press that it was Mrs Kelly and Mr Whalan from the Labor side who led the denunciations of the idea of integration. I am delighted that Senator Ryan, as an Australian Capital Territory representative, has finally decided to follow suit.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall now proceed to the discovery of formal business. The first matter is Business of the Senate, notice of motion No. 1, standing in the name of Senator Harradine for the disallowance of certain regulations.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Gareth Evans-I rise on a point of order, Mr President, in relation to Senator Harradine's motion. The point of order is that it is not competent for the Senate to entertain this motion. The terms of the motion state:
That the World Heritage (Western Tasmania Wilderness) Regulations, as contained in Statutory Rules 1983 No. 31 and made under the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975, be disallowed.

The reality of the situation is that those regulations no longer exist. In fact, as a matter of law, they never did exist because they were beyond the competence of the Executive to promulgate as was so held in the Tasmanian dams case. Senator Harradine is asking us to debate whether regulations which no longer exist and, indeed, which never did exist, should be disallowed.

The Standing Orders of this place make it competent for the Senate to entertain motions of this kind only when they relate to the disallowance of a regulation. Alternatively, to the extent that they enable the Senate to entertain such a motion they do not, I suggest, allow the Senate to give precedence to such a motion ahead of Government Business, the reason being that within the strict language of Standing Order No. 119 we are not here dealing with a motion for the disallowance of a regulation. Whatever we are dealing with it is not the disallowance of a regulation because there is no regulation that could possibly be disallowed.

Lest there be any doubt about that state of affairs, Mr President, I mention to you the circumstances in which the High Court of Australia produced the result that it did. The regulations in question were made, of course, pursuant to section 69 of the National Parks and Wildlife Conservation Act 1975. They were declared to be wholly invalid-of course, other aspects of that legislation were not so declared-by a majority of the High Court in its decision handed down on 31 July 1983, well after Senator Harradine originally gave notice of this motion . The Chief Justice, Sir Harry Gibbs, and Justices Wilson and Dawson found that section 69 was not supported in relevant respect by the external affairs power. The fourth judge to constitute the majority on this point, Mr Justice Deane, found that the regulations as they had been amended by the later World Heritage Properties Consevation Act involved an acquisition of property without the provision of just terms. So what was being held here was that the regulations were invalid for want of power to enact them in the first place. The situation is to be distinguished from that which prevails when a Commonwealth law overrides a State law for inconsistency under section 109 of the Constitution. There it is invalidity of a different sort because the State law in question is capable of revival, of springing back to life, in the event that the Commonwealth law is subsequently repealed or otherwise ruled out of order. But here the regulations simply never did exist. They existed, of course, to the extent that they were written down, printed and circulated. To that extent they appear, in a sense, on the statute book. But equally the effect of the High Court decision was to make their existence something which was purely of a physical kind. They simply did not exist as a matter of law and when that statute book or those regulations are reprinted, the regulations in question will in fact not be reprinted because they will no longer exist-in fact they never have. That is exactly, of course, what happens when regulations are disallowed. They have a life for a time but when they are disallowed they no longer exist. What we are being asked to do is to disallow something which simply does not exist in any tangible form at the moment.

I put it to you, Mr President, that we would be faced with a quite farcical situation were this motion allowed to proceed. We would have those supporting the motion arguing that regulations which do not exist should be disallowed and we would have those on this side of the chamber opposing the motion, no doubt because they wanted the spirit of the regulations to linger on, if not their flesh, arguing that regulations which do not exist should nonetheless not be disallowed. With respect, Mr President, whatever else might be involved in the conduct of proceedings in this chamber it would reduce those proceedings to low farce and be quite inconsonant with whatever dignity the Australian Parliament retains for us to embark upon an enterprise of that particular kind. Medieval theologians used to debate how many angels could dance on the head of a pin. That would look a positively simple exercise by camparison with the kind of metaphysics which would be involved in this case.

The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to give effect to a new River Murray Waters Agreement between the Commonwealth, New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia for the control and management of certain water resources of the River Murray System. The new Agreement is set out in the Schedule to this Bill.

From the earliest days of Federation, the Commonwealth has demonstrated a strong interest in River Murray matters, initially reflecting its concern for interstate trade implications of river traffic, but more importantly in latter times, a recognition of the national importance of water conservation and associated land development based on the River Murray. In fact, River Murray problems, which were already claiming a good deal of attention from 1880 onwards , probably accelerated the advent of Federation.

Multi-State aspects of the River Murray waters were alluded to constantly during the great convention debates which preceded Federation. In these debates, the controversial and contested issues relating to River Murray management were identified.

The first River Murray Waters Agreement, to resolve developing conflicts in the use of River Murray waters, was signed in 1914, legislation came into effect in 1915 and the River Murray Commission was established in 1917. The new Agreement now before this Parliament is the result of the first major review of this important inter-governmental Agreement since those early days.

River water quality, particularly in respect of salinity, has now become a key factor in the long-term utilisation of what is regarded by many as the nation's most important water resource. Under the new Agreement, the responsibilities of the River Murray Commission have been extended to include water quality matters, in addition to the responsibilities it has had in the past for water quantity in the main stem of the river and associated storages.

The new Agreement charges the River Murray Commission with the responsibility for monitoring the quality of water in the river, in tributary inflows and in the Commission's storages. To this end, a monitoring network is already well established.

The Agreement also authorises the River Murray Commission to formulate water quality objectives or standards for key locations along the river. It is against these objectives or standards that the Commission will have to develop its water management strategies.

State authorities are required to inform the Commission of proposals under their consideration which could have a significant effect on water quality or quantity in the river, and to provide the information necessary to enable their likely impact to be assessed. Obviously, the agreed water quality objectives will provide important benchmarks in this region, and the Commission will then make representations, as necessary, to the appropriate State authority on such proposals.

Also worth noting, the water distribution provisions have been completely recast to ensure, not only an equitable distribution of water between the States , but also to allow each State maximum flexibility in meeting its own particular water demands. Even more importantly, the provisions will enable account to be taken of the quality of tributary inflows and drainage returns to the river from each State in assessing their respective shares of the water resources under the Commission's control. This procedure should provide a strong incentive to each State to improve the quality of flows in its tributaries and from outfalls to the river.

In keeping with modern water management principles, the new Agreement now comprehends important river water management objectives for the Commission, additional to its traditional role of supplying water for irrigation. These could include flood mitigation, environmental protection, recreational uses, etc .

For over 65 years, the Commission has operated within the powers defined for it by the four Governments. With the enlargement of these powers to encompass water quality, inter-governmental co-operation in the management of the river system now enters a more difficult phase.

As in every river system, water quality is the end product of practically all major activities in the vast catchment of the River Murray-dryland agriculture, irrigation, forestry and urban/industrial development. These are all areas of State responsibility, and the realities of the Australian Constitution require that many of the Commission's water quality responsibilities may have to be pursued in consultation and co-operation with the States. While in these areas the Commission will have mainly an advisory role, its powers of persuasion should not be underestimated, particularly if its representations are based on well researched data and are consistent with the overall thrust of the new Agreement.

The Government will be maintaining a close interest in the implementation of the new Agreement and, if there are indications that the Agreement needs to be strengthened, we will approach the three States to determine how this might be done.

The Commission retains its autonomy under the new Agreement. This is essential if it is to continue as an effective custodian in the national interest of this most important water resource, and to provide the stimulus for co-operative action by the states in the maintenance and, eventually, improvement of water quality in the River Murray.

The Government believes that the new Agreement provides a more adequate framework for inter-governmental co-operation in the development of long-term plans for safeguarding the enormous public and private investment in irrigation settlements and urban water supply systems based on the River Murray in the three States. This Agreement, as was the case with its predecessor, depends on the goodwill of the contracting parties for its success.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

Mr Deputy President, this amendment was suggested originally by the Law Council of Australia. It has also found comment in the annual report of the Family Law Council. The proposal is to deal with the problem which arises because applications for approval of maintenance agreements can be dealt with by magistrates courts. The present situation is that very important considerations may have to be taken into account in a determination, including questions of property of an enourmous value. Magistrates courts could determine an agreement without adequate advice and without any of the facilities of the Family Court to help them. These agreements come under section 87 of the Family Law Act. For some considerable time the Family Law Council, in particular, has been drawing attention to the undesirable practice of retaining so much jurisdiction in the magistrates courts. Likewise, the Law Council of Australia drew attention to this matter in submissions it made in commenting on the original 1981 Bill. At that time, in referring to a sub-section as it then was, it said:

This sub-section retains the power of courts of summary jurisdiction to approve maintenance agreements under s.87 of the Family Law Act 1975. The Committee made submissions to the Joint Select Committee of the Federal Parliament suggesting that the jurisdiction of courts of summary jurisdiction be limited to the enforcement of maintenance agreements and maintenance orders. It did so in the belief that the qualifications and training of personnel constituting such courts do not always permit proper consideration of all relevant factors in important matters between husband and wife.
It is notable that the Bill preserves the limitation of the jurisdiction of courts of summary jurisdiction over applications for alteration of interests in property below $1,000 in value.

It appears inconsistent that such courts can consider the approval of maintenance agreements under s.87 of the Act, when it is often the case that property of very considerable value is involved, and when it is remembered that the agreement provides for a complete release by the parties of all claims under the Family Law Act, and that such agreements are normally incapable of cancellation.

In the recent case of Van der Veer it was held that a maintenance agreement approved by a court of summary jurisdiction ceases to be binding if either party appeals from the order approving the agreement. This is a further unsatisfactory aspect of permitting courts of summary jurisdiction to approve such agreements.
It is therefore submitted that courts of summary jurisdiction should no longer be empowered to approve agreements made under s.87 of the Act.

I propose with this amendment to remove this power but to include the exception, in brackets, 'unless such approval has been given by the court prior to the coming into operation of this sub-section'. One can understand that if that has already happened then one should not deal retrospectively with that situation. Otherwise, I believe this should be done. Likewise, the Family Law Council has long urged that action be taken to reduce the jurisdiction which is to be found in the magistrates courts in regard to important matters like this. I urge that this amendment be carried.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Notwithstanding again the apparent compelling character of the considerations advanced by Senator Missen, I believe there are good reasons why this amendment should be opposed. Clause 14 of the Bill as it presently stands, which amends section 39 of the principal Act, will enable that to occur. So again, whilst appreciating the general force of what Senator Missen is saying, the Government cannot accept this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It being after 7 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: The the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise again tonight in a sense of some outrage arising from my discussion last night in the adjournment debate of the question of the wine tax. Some people who were in the chamber at the time might remember that I tried to address a question to the Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) as to whether he may deem it fit to take to his colleague the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Kerin) the complaints made by the industry. I wanted to convey to the Government the very deep concern of the people of South Australia on this issue. As honourable senators may recall, my Labor colleague from South Australia, Senator Crowley, prevented me from asking that question last night. I now ask it. I would like to hear whether the Attorney-General has any conclusive information which can demonstrate whether the Government is prepared to consider the very significant problems of South Australian wine makers who have a very real difficulty in financing significant sums associated with the excise that will be imposed as a result of the legislation yet to be brought down.

SPEECH.PARA: I reiterate the point that when a grape spirit maker makes a spirit and is then obliged to use it in the making of ports, brandies, sherries or muscats, then, within seven days thereafter, he has to pay an excise to the Commonwealth in order to comply with the arrangements that are now being outlined. That system has been presented forward by this Government as being a carry-through of an old system of excise which was applicable to wine and other spirits of this kind in times past. I make the point that that is not correct and it cannot simply be justified on those grounds.

Last night I pointed out that if wine makers in this situation use grape spirit to fortify port wine and if that port is a significant and quality wine, perhaps some 15 years will elapse before he can recover from the person to whom he sells the port the excise that he paid seven days after mixing the spirit with the port. This is an outrageous attempt to drag working capital out of wine makers' businesses so far ahead of the final product. It is fair to say that it is possible that the material might be destroyed while maturing. In fact it is certain that a very large proportion of it, estimated at around 2 1/2 per cent, and perhaps even as high as 10 per cent, may have evaporated in the meantime and is a straight loss to the wine maker. There is one other point to be made in regard to the old system of excise which the Treasurer, Mr Keating, would have us believe is being carried on in this tax that he is bringing down.

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean the newly discredited Treasurer.

—The newly discredited Treasurer, Mr Keating. He compared the 1970 system of applying excise. In those days, on a comparable basis, the excise applicable would have been 15.4c per litre of alcohol. Today, as evidenced by Budget Paper No. 2, the tax that will be applied is $2.61 per litre of alcohol. Consequently, the increase is about 17 times what it was in 1970. By no means can the Government claim that this is a mere extension of a previous system of excise collection.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that the Attorney-General was tired last night. He commented to the effect that the whole debate was tedious. I believe he probably meant that the debate about the wine tax was certainly tedious. Consequently, I did not get from him any response that recognised the point that I was making in regard to the need to finance these costs of excise for such long periods during which the final product would be matured. He raved on about some irrelevant factors that related to the actual cost per bottle of this particular excise and he sought to describe it as something like 25c a bottle. Of course, he did not acknowledge the enormous costs of financing that money over the life of maturation of the product nor did he acknowledge the problems of evaporation of the product over that period which, as I have said, can be as long as 15 years or longer. Neither did he acknowledge that there is a considerable physical problem in storing these things and the consequent costs involved. The cost of excise adds to those extra costs.

It is that question that I will be bringing to the attention of the Attorney- General. I hope that he will see fit to take that to his colleague and obtain a reply and, I hope, a reconsideration of that aspect of the tax in order to have it aligned with the previous method by which excise was levied in these situations, which was that the tax would be payable at the point of release for sale of the final product, not at the time at which it is blended into the material of which it is a raw ingredient. From that point of view there is a very significant question at issue. It is one which raises very considerable concern because it really challenges the viability of wine makers in South Australia who use the spirit specifically for the purposes of making fortified wines.

I stated last night that this Bill has a very uneven effect right across the Commonwealth, particularly in my State of South Australia where 65 per cent of the grape spirit is used. Not only will it affect the State as a whole but also it will severely impact on a particular part of the State, that is, the irrigated wine areas of the riverland-those parts around Renmark, Berri and Barmera-in South Australia. I draw those things to his attention because it could quite possibly be that as much as $16m will be ripped out of that part of the South Australian economy, with a very detrimental effect. I look to the Attorney-General for his comments. If he is unable to provide them tonight, I certainly hope that he will take this very significant concern to his colleague and obtain a reply and a very serious and overall comprehensive review of the impact of this tax before the final legislation is brought down.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This week the Hawke Labor Government has torpedoed the Australian film industry. The actions taken this week by the Government in relation to the film industry will have the effect, I predict, of ruining prospects of private investment in the film industry in Australia. I do not seek to pre-empt the debate on the subject matter of taxation legislation that will come forward in this session, but I seek to place on the record that, because of a lack of understanding of taxation concessions for the film industry , the industry will find itself very soon in a grave predicament.

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of the Government's changes to tax arrangements is two-fold. The first effect is that they have brought great uncertainty, yet again, to the industry. The Government promised two years of stability in the most recent tax measures, that is those passed by the Parliament in May this year. Only three months later the Government has changed the rules again and thrown the Australian film industry into turmoil. Of course, the Government could have changed the rules a little by keeping one of its election promises-that relating to tax deductibility of the cost of marketing films. That promise was not kept and another promise of stability and no change for two years have been broken by the most recent tax measures. Some publicity has been given in the Press today to the reactions of the film industry. I want to support very strongly those reactions because they were the conclusions I drew after looking at the Budget Speech on Tuesday night.

Some people have thought that because the term 150 per cent tax write-off is used, if investors spend, let us say, $1m on producing a film, $1.5 passes into the hands of the investors. Of course, that is not true. The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr Cohen), in his speech to the Parliament on 25 May 1983, went to the length of pointing out that the 150 per cent tax deduction is effectively only a 128 per cent tax deduction. In any event at that point the investment is still not fully returned. The Minister went on to look at the collective effect of a 150 per cent tax write-off plus a tax exemption of 50 per cent of the investment and to point out that the result was that, on the figures with a $1m investment, the break-even point was approximately $240,000. The Minister said:

It was true that if an investor put $1m into a film with an effective tax write -off of 128 per cent, he needed a return of approximately only $240,000 to break even. However, three out of five films did not return $240,000. This is the most important point that the people must remember. One out of five broke even and the fifth went into profit.

Therefore the second effect of the changes announced by the Government on Tuesday night-the lowering of the tax write-off to 133 per cent and the lowering of the tax exemption-is such that many films will not reach break-even point, far fewer than previously did. The Minister has put great emphasis in the past on the fact of how few films have reached break-even point. The effective raising of the break-even point by 10 per cent has meant that fewer films will reach break-even point and even fewer will make a profit. Further, the investor will pay tax on the film's income at least at the point where the film passes into profit, and possibly before it has even reached the break-even point. The reason he will pay tax in a loss situation is that Labor has not honoured its election promise to allow the cost of marketing a film to be tax deductible.

The effect of these government actions on private investment is, of course, obvious. The film industry has had its problems in recent times in attracting investment. It has been suggested that the late passage of the taxation amending legislation in May of this year was responsible for the low level of investment for 1982-83 and that perhaps investment might lift in the future. The message to investors now is clear. The chances of an Australian made film making a profit and returning a profit to the investor are even more remote than they previously were in this notoriously high risk industry. Investors have a major disincentive to stay away from the film industry as a result of the decisions of this Government. On the other hand, the Government tells us that in return for a saving of $4m in tax, it will put $5m into the Australian Film Commission. I predict that the Government will save far less than $4m because private investors will not put money into the industry under these new conditions. The Minister for Home Affairs and Environment made a statement yesterday on the subject of the $5m that will be given to the Australian Film Commission. I have nothing against the Australian Film Commission. I think it has done some very good work. But quite clearly the advantage that a film will have now if it is supported by the Australian Film Commission becomes overwhelming in the light of what I have said about the effect of the Government's measures on private investment.

I am sure that the Minister is very genuine in his positive attitude towards the Australian film industry. I have never had any reason to suspect otherwise. I believe that the Minister sitting in the chamber now, the Minister who represents him, the Minister for Education and Youth Affairs (Senator Ryan), is also very genuine in her interest in the Australian film industry. However, I fear that it is likely that those who have understood the arithmetic and who have understood the consequences of the Government's decision have not had their way in Cabinet. I do not say that lightly-it is always an easy comment to make. But there are on the record statements by other members of the present Cabinet about the tax concessions that were previously obtained. Most notably, there have been statements in the Senate by Senator Peter Walsh, who when in opposition referred in debate on these subjects to the previous taxation measures as a rort and pork-barrelling exercise. Senator Walsh in his statements on those taxation concessions showed no understanding of what the concessions amounted to and exhibited the same sort of blind prejudice as we were treated to by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in his statement on Tuesday night on who had been benefiting in the film industry.

Thousands of people owe their jobs to private investment in the Australian film industry. That is not thousands of actors-a relatively small number of actors can be taken out of the total. But the total number of people who earn their livings from the Australian film industry, who earn their incomes from private investment in the film industry, in the technical and production areas and in other areas, is very large indeed. These people face, at a stroke, a bleak future despite having been promised a stable one. The rhetoric of the Treasurer in saying who would be the losers by these changes in the taxation concessions showed no sensitivity towards, or knowledge of, the number of people whose jobs are now threatened.

I return to the grant of $5m to the Australian Film Commission for investment in films. I am alarmed at the message that comes through in the Government's attitude to this. The Minister has said that the production of films of high quality with potential for commercial viability will be further encouraged by Government investment through the Australian Film Commission. Those with proposals to make films and those who seek to produce films face a very poor prospect of getting private investment in their films. Obviously they will turn to the Australian Film Commission for investment. An amount of $5m, of itself, will not make a major contribution to very many feature films. But for those who will now be competing for a very much reduced level of investment, that $5m held by the Australian Film Commission will be overwhelmingly irresistible. If the Commission is to pursue anything other than a totally objective and impartial policy on the content of those films, the film industry is indeed in for a bleak time.

I agree that films should be of a high quality if they are to have public investment. I agree that there should be a judgment made as to commercial viability. I do not agree that it is very easy to judge that. In the Senate on 2 June I asked a question in relation to a statement that the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment had made about Australian films that had become profitable. On 3 June the Minister for Social Security (Senator Grimes) had that list of films incorporated in Hansard. I seek leave to have that list incorporated in Hansard on this occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is an interesting list. It is interesting to me in that I had not heard of some of the films and can only speculate what the content of certain of them was. Perhaps it is not surprising that I have not heard of them. Mr Deputy President, you look puzzled. I did not want to do an injustice to a film. One is called Libido and another is called Fantasm. As I said, I do not know anything about them but the image their titles project is of a very particular type. I might be quite wrong. Maybe the subject of the films was something that does not appear obvious from their titles. However it is interesting that approximately half of the films that have been profitable are what we would call not elevating. They may be entertaining. There are films like Adventures of Barry McKenzie, Bazza Holds His Own, Alvin Purple and Alvin Rides Again. They are films that some people would choose not to see. But they are obviously films that a large number of people have chosen to see because they made a profit. The other half of the list includes films such as Picnic at Hanging Rock, Caddie, Gallipoli, My Brilliant Career and Breaker Morant. Some people would say these were high quality films, but not necessarily all would enjoy them.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the list demonstrates that people are very varied in their tastes in films. If people were to use some sort of measure of what is a film of high quality they could well overlook the sort of film which, according to its existence on this list, has the ability to be profitable. For example, Puberty Blues was a very low budget film. I suspect that if I just read some outline of the screen play of that film I might have thought that it had the potential of being a not very high quality film. Yet, it is a sensitive, worthwhile film. I am concerned that a semi-government body will have such an important bearing on what films will actually be made in Australia. I ascribe to the Australian Film Commission no motive of malice or elitism, but it concerns me that it will now have such a strong influence in determining which films are made, particularly when the Minister in his statement has made many comments of a highly subjective nature on what constitutes a high quality film. For example, he said:
Much effort has been wasted by Ministers and my Department in the certification process in considering proposals for films that were never likely to enter production.

I do not know how that judgment of likelihood to enter production can be made in advance by the Department of Home Affairs and Environment, but obviously there is some value judgment abroad in that Department. Terms have been used by the Minister such as 'quality', 'acceptable standard' and 'doubtful merit'. I am not asserting that the Minister would direct the Australian Film Commission, but he is very close to it and apparently has very definite views on what is an ' acceptable standard', 'quality' and 'merit'. That is very disturbing indeed.

The film industry is rightly upset by Government action this week. Film producers rightly regard the future as very ominous indeed. I thought in May that we had made a step forward and the film industry welcomed it. A bipartisan measure came to this Parliament in relation to taxation and the film industry and a promise of stability was given. The film industry, for all its enthusiasm on that occasion, must indeed now feel shattered and wonder what it did wrong. Did it make films that the Minister considers to be of doubtful quality and merit? Are they films that are on the profitable list? How can the Minister possibly justify the Government's actions? The Minister has, of course, been very defensive on the subject and I do not blame him. I am sure he is not very happy about the position he has been put in. The Minister undoubtedly will survive to bring more legislation on films into this Parliament but many other Australians now know that they will not see a future in which they will be part of an Australian film industry.

On further examination it appears that $27m is provided as a maximum amount subject to negotiation of particular projects. That amounts to less than a quarter of the claim for the first year made by Tasmania. That claim for the first year is simply in respect of two of the promises made by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and other Ministers on behalf of this Government to continue the employment of the people who were put out of work as a result of the stopping of the dam and compensate for the damage to Tasmania, including the expenses to date. I can only draw to the Minister's attention the way in which compound interest works. If the Minister does not understand, I invite him to get a quick lesson in compound interest. But the point I make to him is that the longer this Government delays paying anything to Tasmania-it has not paid a cent to date-the more concerned will Tasmanians and, I imagine, every decent Australian become and the more the amount of compensation due to Tasmania will compound. TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to respond briefly to matters that have been raised by Opposition senators in the adjournment debate tonight. I have been asked by the Attorney-General, Senator Evans, to comment briefly on the matter raised by Senator Messner when the Attorney-General was in the chamber and I was not. SPEECH.PARA: Senator Martin took the opportunity to express her views on the recently announced changes to the tax concessions available for investment in Australian films. At the outset I say that I still welcome the fact that Senator Martin and the Opposition generally wish to have a bipartisan policy of support for the Australian film industry. The industry has been through turbulent times over the last few years and it is certainly the intention of this Government to introduce an element of stability that has previously been lacking. Senator Martin does not agree that the decision made by the Government in the last couple of days is a step in that direction but I expect that events will prove her wrong. The Australian Government is very committed to the Australian film industry, not only because, as Senator Martin rightly points out, it is a large employer of people with a wide range of skills, but also because it has become a focus for expression of national identity in a way that no previous art form has achieved. I know that you, Mr Deputy President, probably of all honourable senators in this place, are aware of the achievements of the Australian film industry over recent years. We all rejoice in that and we all wish it to continue. The question arises as to how best to ensure future investment, public and private, in the Australian film industry at a level which will secure stability, which will enable innovation, change and development and which will ensure that the films that Australians can identify with, enjoy and be proud of are the films which are making a reputation for Australia internationally.

The changes that the Government has made to tax concessions available for investment in films are minor amendments. They are not drastic changes. There is a reallocation of the form in which our support for the film industry will be carried out. I think that everybody interested in the film industry and everybody who has followed its turbulent history in recent years will agree that if investment in films has mainly the purpose of providing a tax haven for private investors, then some distortions and reduction in quality inevitably follow. It has been the view of many people in the film industry that there has been investment in films which has not brought with it any genuine interest in the kinds of films being made but has simply sought to utilise the tax haven that such investment is able to provide. There have been distortions in the film industry. Many films have been made for which substantial concessions have been available, which have not been successful, not only because they have not managed to break into the profit producing area-I agree with Senator Martin that it is very difficult to get a profitable return on an Australian film because of various cost factors-but also because they were no good. I do not think that anyone who works in the film industry would argue with that view.

There have been other kinds of distortions, too, in terms of employment opportunities, the availability of crews and things of this kind, which flowed from the problems that the industry experienced when the tax concessions were available for only a very short period. The film had to be made, produced and earning income within 12 months. We have corrected that situation and allowed a two year timetable for the production of a film. This will allow for a much more orderly development of the film industry. As to whether the level of concessions available-they are still very generous-will attract a sufficient level of private investment, I can only say that time will tell. I know that my colleague , the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, Mr Barry Cohen, is firmly convinced, after extensive consultations with the film industry, that they will.

I am very supportive of the way in which we have changed our support for the film industry, in that money saved from adjusting the tax concession will be given to the Australian Film Commission for direct public investment in films. There is no doubt that we would not have had an Australian film industry if we had not had extensive public investment. The early histories of the South Australian Film Corporation, the New South Wales Film Corporation and the Australian Film Commission all provide evidence that, because of our particular circumstances of population and isolation from the rest of the world, and the fact that we are a small part of a huge global English speaking population, we have needed a public investment base for our film industry. We have such a base and we have had a successful film industry. This Government wants to see the right balance between public and private investment. But it is the view of the Government that there will always be a need for solid public investment in the Australian film industry, for direct investment into feature films. The Australian Film Commission and certainly the New South Wales and South Australia film corporations have good records of investment in Australian films.

There is also the fact that public investment can fund things that will not attract private investments, but are nevertheless very important. One area in which we would like to see the Film Commission more active and supportive is that of creative development activities. It should assist new film makers, film writers and so forth who, because they do not have established reputations, would not be able to attract extensive private investment. If we do not nurture new talent, which is necessary in any area of creative activity, we will not have a film industry in 10 years time. Therefore we judged that it was very important to improve the capacity of the Australian Film Commission to support creative development. The decisions announced by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in the last couple of days will do that.

Senator Martin raised the question-not of censorship; I do not wish to be unjust to her-of the connection between the expressed subjective values of the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment and the kinds of films which the Australian Film Commission would support. It is entirely reasonable that people in the film industry want to know what the Minister responsible for this activity thinks about films. I congratulate my colleague Barry Cohen on being very active, available, accessible and frank in his dealings as a new Minister with this industry, but it would be quite wrong to assume that because he is interested in a certain kind of film-as indeed I am, or Senator Martin or Senator Hamer would be-that that would somehow become a charter for investment for the Australian Film Commission. It is an independent statutory body. We believe that the film industry and the Australian Government are best served by that independence being maintained and clearly recognised and appreciated by people in the film industry.

I do not lack any confidence in the capacity of the Film Commission to make wise investments with the additional money it will get. It will not back a winner every time because, as everyone knows, that is impossible not only at the races but also in the film industry. However, its track record is good enough for us to feel confident that it will continue to provide a major source of support for the film industry. We also express the hope and the expectation that the reputation of Australian films is now so high that serious private investment which is linked with the outcome in terms of the kinds of films produced and not just utilising a tax haven, will combine to provide a burgeoning and lively film industry over the next few decades.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
